number of helpful: 61 of 74 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												You can create a rocket launcher made out of pipes and fireworks, and boxing gloves with knifes attached to them, what's not to love?Dead rising 2 is a  good zombie slaugthering time, even with it's annoyences and issues.The game takes place a few years after the first one and follows chuck greene, a motorcycle rider/father, who is framed for the zombie outbreak on fortune city. Story is fairly decent, but it's not the game's strongest aspect. There is multiple endings, but ending A and S are the only ones worth getting.Describing the type of game dead rising is, is rather tricky since it's in a league of it's, however what I can call it is that it's a beat em up hack n slash third person shooting open world rpg, or you can just call it an action rpg.Combat is slow and kind of annoying, but somehow in the end it's so fun slicing and bashing zombies. You can use anything as a weapon from knifes,guns (which are quite fun to use), brooms, to wheelchairs even. However each item breaks, which makes the game kind of refreshing.One of the elements of the game that makes it so much fun is the combo cards, which allow you to take 2 items you find. You need to go to a maintenance room for it.There is an rpg element in the sense that you will level up with PP. How do you get PP? Kill Kill and Kill, and also completing side missions which involves Rescuing survivors(which is kind of annoying, but tolerable if you find the leadership magazine) and fighting psychopaths(Optional boss battles that are generally enjoyable to fight).the game also has a Timer which will turn a lot of people off....on the first playthrough, on the 2nd since you are at a higher level it's no big deal.Dead rising 2 may not be technically impressive, but the game is never afraid to show something visually appealing and the animations are fairly good.Sound is good, the music is ranges from lounge music, rock, to atmospheric music which fits well with the goofy nature of the game.Dead rising 2 may not appeal to everyone, but what it does it's does it quite well.7/10

number of helpful: 44 of 48 people (92%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
												Five years and two platforms later, still a fantastic, unique title.+ Story is interesting, albeit a tad contrived. Servicable voice acting, decent plot and a good protagonist make uncovering the next story event something to look forward to.+ Lively, well developed characters.+ Myriad of fun and effective weapons. Combine two weapons into one of extreme power. Combo weapons are creative and worth the hassle. + Leveling up your character gives rewarding incentive to do some sandbox and replays.+ Fantastically recorded and generated sound assets.+ Fortune City is a colorful, enjoyable map with plenty of fun and surprises.+ Zombies are dismembered in satisfying, dynamic ways.+ Visuals are obviously dated but serviceable.+ Decent amount of PC options. Controls are relatively problem free. Not a Mad Max quality port, but certainly a giant leap from something Arkham Knight quality. + Co-op can ease up more difficult missions and add substantial enjoyment to the slaughter.+ Vehicles are a great transportation/murder tool, even if the controls can be a bit over/under compensating.- The timer is the biggest controversy of this game. I personally hate being paced, stressed, and rushed. The only reason I reccomend this game is because you can disable/slow the timer with mods and trainers. The timer adds a decent challenge to the game but leaves little time for fun screwing around or side missions.- Competetive online is dead, but it was never really "all that" in the first place. Fairly generic "American Gladiator"-esque challenges that involve zombie death.- Side missions; particularly the survivor escorts, are repetetive and pretty boring. Survivors can slow you down and become a time wasting liability.- Although the "psychopath" boss fights are memorable and contain great characters, they are rather annoying and dependant on your level rather than your skill and adaptability. They often boil down to the same "dodge this then hit me" formula.- Some combat mechanics wear thin quick and become a chore. Shaking your mouse in a QTE to shed a grappling zombie (which happens OFTEN), getting knocked flat on your♥♥♥♥♥and stunned by almost all human attacks, stopping to cough sporatically when the later introduced enemy attacks you.- Normal, non-combo weapons feel a bit underpowered for the most part. Firearms have their damage heavily reduced against human enemies for no explained reason. Uncombined melee and throwable weapons break very quickly and yield very little experience.Overall, Chuck Greene's a pretty cool guy who makes pretty cool weapons and kills zombies in pretty cool ways in a pretty cool set-piece. The only overbearing cons are the timer which can be circumvented via mods and the lousy side-missions which are totally optional. Picked up for about $7 which justifies almost thirty hours of play.

number of helpful: 42 of 55 people (76%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
A bit about the game and developers.Dead Rising 2 is a sequel to a zombie slaying game - Dead Rising. Dead Rising 2 is set a bit after Dead Rising, but has nothing to do with the original game. Dead Rising 2 has been developed by Blue Castle Games, and published by Capcom! It's funny how Capcom has so many well known zombie games...About Gameplay.Dead Rising 2 is an open world zombie survival game. In Dead Rising 2 you have couple of missions (one main mission and a lot of side missions) which you do not need to follow at all! You see, Dead Rising 2 is a game in which you can do almost anything. Grab a motorbike, put a chainsaw on it and run over zombies. Or grab a motorbike, put machine gun on it and kill more zombies! Or just run around with nothing but a blade in your hands, chopping down everything in your path. The ways you can kill this zombies are almost limitless!What makes this game far better than the first one is co-op option! You can call a friend to play this game with you and destroy the zombies with you! It's very fun indeed! Imagine two motorbikes with chainsaws, just driving down the street, ending every single zombie's life that is currently present.  This game also gives you and ability to craft a weapon out of two other weapons. For example, with a broom and a machete you make something like a spear. With knife and boxing gloves you make razor claws. With nails and a baseball bat... Very deadly baseball bat! You get the point - it's extremely fun!So, as I said, you can chose to do the mission or you could just chose to ignore it and have loads of fun in the game. The game has six different endings, which all happen with a reason. For example, if you do whole main mission and then chose option A on some point (i don't plan to give out any spoilers!) You'll get first and best ending. If you do main mission and chose option B, you'll get almost same thing as A case. Everything else is more or less failure.The game also futures a four person co-op in which all you can do is drive around a small area on a motorcycle and kill tones and tones and tones of zombies. I can't tell you much about that because I never managed to get into a game. There are just not enough players that play it..Graphic and AudioGraphically speaking the game looks very very sweet. There's just enough blood, the zombies are quite detailed and everything seems in place. They could have added more different looking zombies though. Audio is very awesome and never gets too boring to listen to! It keeps changing as you enter stores, menu and so on and on. Only positive thoughts about Audio of this game!Pros, cons and final grade.Pros:- Great co op fun.- A lot of different clothing and weapons.- Audio never gets boring.- A lot of vehicles.- You can keep on playing even if you decide not to do missions.Cons:- Main mission forces you to wait a long time before continuing the story..- Only two people co op.- No players so the 4 person co-op is impossible without friends.- The game uses Games for Windows Live so it might become unplayable next year since GFWL is going down..Overall grade: 8.5 / 10Extra info: This is an amazing zombie killing game to pass the time. I really enjoyed playing it with a friend of mine, Mr.Trolla. Thank you for playing the game with me!Thank you for reading my reviews! Don't forget that I'm usually posting new reviews on my blog weekly and you can check them out here:[/b] http://midnightwolfie.blogspot.comThank you![/b]

content:
Posted: January 6, 2012
												Note: This game been tried out and reviewed in Steam offline mode or on Consoles.Dead Rising 2 stays true to the heart of Dead Rising 1.In other words, it feels and plays just like DR1 except it's, well, better. Pictures/camera have been replaced with custom weapons (much more fun), the AI has been drastically improved, the text size has been enlarged (finally), and no more annoying Otis.Essentially, however, this game is a love/hate kind of deal. If you didn't like DR1, chances are,you're not going to like DR2.It follows the same overall system.You start out incredibly weak, you level up, psychopaths can be -extremely- hard, and dying is generally unforgiving (although this time around, having 3 save files really does help quite a bit).Overall: If this doesn't sound like your thing, you'd best avoid the game. If you loved DR1, however, strap up and get ready for a satisfying, bloody, romp-ride. Well...that and coffee creamers. Plus: you will get to see my Twins.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												I don't know about Windows 7 or below, but if you have Windows 8 then DO NOT BUY.  This game requires Games for Windows Live which has been a major pain to get working and set up.The game installed so I tried to play it.  It required me to install Games for Windows but gave an error when it tried.  After searching through the internet for various fixes that did not help, I uninstalled the Games for Windows it tried to install.  I then installed it directly from the windows website.  It again did not work.  I uninstalled again and installed from the xbox website.  It now loaded up but gave me an error when trying to sign in with my windows live information.  The error is vague and I had to search it as well.  Apparently you have to manually login through the xbox website or through an xbox to accept the terms and conditions.  Games for windows is now working so I booted up Dead Rising.  Oh wait, there's an update needed for games for windows!  The update has failed 3 times now as it tries to shut down games for windows and instead just stalls and freezes.  Still trying...will update later...TL:DR: Games for Windows is total garbage and ruins the experience of even TRYING to play this game on a PC.Edit:  I can now get the game to start up and play, we'll see how it goes from here.  It is ridiculous that it took me over two hours to get it to run.  And this seems to be a known issue that a lot of people are having.  Nothing is simplified in fixing this issue and you have to research it.  I still advise to just buy it on console and not on PC.

Posted: June 10, 2016
												Dad Rising 2 - A Game About Spoiling Your Daughter With Gifts, Crossdressing, and Gambling. (With an optional but forced zombie, and survivor rescue minigame)Rescuing survivors can be a good deal of fun since it makes your PP go up quicker than when killing zombies and a few give you lots of goodies such as drugs (for ur daughter) and money. However there are some survivors that deserve your wrath, the wrath of zombies, or to get sniped by /pol/. I have a few stories of such survivors, if I wasn't going for Otis's outfit I would've let them die.Survivor 1: Some gambling addict in the silver strip, he wouldnt move until he wins or I pay him 20k, I had an abundance of money on my second playthrough so I gladly paid him 20k so he can get a move on, then he goes "How about an extra 5k ;))))" I was angry, I paid the 5k and I just kept calling him, didn't care if a zombie grappled him, gambling kills people.Survivors 2,3,4: A bunch of women, they wouldnt move until I paid them like 20 something k, don't remember but they were expensive, thankfully I unlocked the hidden Toilet shortcut from Palisades to Royal Flush so that was easier, they later said I should call em for "Protection" it looked like I was the one doing the protecting more.Survivors Worse Joke and Worser Joke: A black guy and a funny dressed old guy, they wont move unless I chose which one of them had the best joke, I thought sure why not, I'm bored and I like jokes. I was unaware that I would be awarding one or the other not for the best joke, but for the least worst joke. tl;dr: Black guy's involves Zombies, Food and ends with Stains, Old Guy involves Vegeterian Zombies, ends with Grains. First playthrough, gave the award to the black guy, seemed like the least horrible joke. Second playthrough I gave the award to the old guy, cause while making my way there I thought his might be a bit better. Black guy says that old men like old jokes, and WONT move until I coughed up 5k. I was dressed as a SWAT officer at the time and highly considered ""arresting"" him with Extreme Prejudice, but I needed Otis's outfit, so I paid 5k and didn't care if he died.Not all survivors are bad, I came across this one guy looking for protection with his casino winnings, got a pistol took him to the safe house and he gave me a whooping 70k, He deserved my protection.Then we had another one that was robbing ATMs, money ($100) would drop from his thing occassionally like candy, I robbed teh ATMs with him, got him to the safe house, nice 50k I think.We also have the good guys, a paramedic that gives me zombrex for rescuing him and getting him alcohol later on, thats 2 whole zombrex.We also have this one fat prick, he wont move until you give him food, but he has drugs and you need them, so you give him food and you take him back to your safehouse, and damn that ♥♥♥♥er acts fast, the moment you rescue him all the food from the cafeteria is gone and is never seen again.Theres also that one side quest about rescuing a plant.

content:
Posted: January 22
Objectively obliterates Dead Rising 1Nearly every grievance I had with the first game has been completely fixed. Escort missions are a breeze when the NPCs aren't walking into walls! This might be the only instance of crafting done amazingly in a video game. Most games feed players the broken down ingredients for basic items like medkits and noise makers. In here you can take a car battery and a wheelchair and create a mobile battering ram electric death trap that you use to rush down throngs of zombies. ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. The yellow tranciever that notifies you of your next mission doesn't paralyze you anymore, and you can quickly cyle through the messages! Even the basic gunplay is now FINALLY viable! You can aim and move your body at the same time!? Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥♥what a scoop!Being able to move and shoot makes the bosses way more reasonable and fair, while still being tough as nails. Before any boss load up on booze and OJ, bring a couple fully loaded shotguns and watch everything fall before you! Don't get overconfident with that setup, many of these bosses will destroy you in an instant if you don't take them seriously. Speaking of which, the cast of psychopaths is every bit as inspired and varied as the first game. One of the bosses is a tiger and you can beat it by feeding it steak and taking it to your home base! Amazing. Now that DR2 has been divorced from GFWL there's no reason to put off playing this game any longer. Out of all the sandbox crafting zombie games, this is my favorite one.

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2
												I absolutely loved Dead Rising, so when I heard about Dead Rising 2 years ago, I must have written it off because they removed the camera functionality. Which is ignorant, because while I enjoyed the Camera system, the real true draw was the stress of the 72-Hour system. Recently I picked DR2 up for myself and my GF, and we have been playing it non-stop in co-op. It is freaking excellent. It has all the wacky psychos, hilarious weapons and terribly bad (assumedly purposefully) writing of the first game.There are some serious negatives for some people, for instance, co-op is barebones, while character progress can be tracked and saved per player, only one players story advances. There are several quirks as well; joining character has no weapons each time you join the game (each play session start basically), and when one player opens the menu it pauses the other players game. I’m sure there’s more, but overall, we have gotten past those issues and still had tons of fun.Another important note for those looking to play on Win 10 with controllers. I had tremendous difficulty getting controllers to work and I am pretty technically competent. I tried many different controllers and described methods from other people and eventually one worked, but I certainly spent a couple hours on the problem, which is crazy to me considering that the game was made for Xbox 360 and I was trying 360 controllers and couldn’t get it to recognize. In conclusion, the game is excellent despite its quirks, if you liked the first one and can get past the little problems, then you will probably love this one. Looking forward to playing the DLC as well.

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												I played this a long♥♥♥♥♥time ago on 360 back in 2010, and heard the initial release of deadrising 2 was botched on pc for many reasons (windows live being a thing unfortunately being one of them). Never completed it, found it difficult to play back in the day, and even now the game can be difficult to play. There are still some issues left even when windows live stopped going on. some of the cutscenes are clearly rendered for 30fps when it is running for 60fps, and the loading times are still long and tedious and in abundance, like the original deadrising and on the xbox 360. unfortunately, it seems regardless of PC specs the load times are long and annoying. The number one complaint I hear about this game is the TIME CONSTRAINTS and how it doesn't allow time to be invested in doing whatever you like completely. For example, getting Katie (your daughter) the drug she needs is something a lot of people really did not want to bother with, but it is obviously a key component to making this zombie game different from the rest. The time constraints for me do not take away from the experience, but rather, make me invest my time well into what things I want to do in the playthrough, like doing certain missions and ones which I can live with missing, saved for another replay.Anyway, besides those obvious issues, the game itself still holds up fantastically, and it makes me sad the game is almost long forgotten at this point, that being obvious with the global achievements tracker showing people that have played this game lately, only 2 percent have beaten it. To me, the game holds up remarkably well, despite its age, and while I haven't played deadrising 3, mainly because of apparent issues with the port on PC, this game still does the series justice. TONS of replayability, the co-op is weird but still amazing to have with a friend, and the soundtrack to this game holds a special place in my heart. for example go look up Kill the Sound by Celldweller, it is a fantastic song from this game's official soundtrack. It is just so sad seeing the game on Steam being long forgotten because of its horrible PC launch probably botching the popularity the game deserves.Overall, if you enjoy co-op zombie games with a million and one creative ways to kill them, don't mind using a plug in controller over mouse and keyboard, like your game to not be taken seriously in most cases (the story is incredibly parody-like and quite self-aware) and do not mind the time constraints, this game is definitely worth a purchase for that experience alone.

												Great,  stressful zombie killing mayhem  game as well as one of the best BARBIE DOLL DRESSUP GAMES out there, but that appplies to all the dead risings! It is fun, but OFF THE RECORD is better for a  couple of reasons.The first one is that Frank West is slightly more fun than Chuck (and sillier), and the other is that photography is more fun than it should be. The second is that Off The Record also has a mode that removes the  time limit! That turns it into one of the best sandbox experiences out there, which is missing in this version.Both games are ridiculously silly, but it is important to remember than in both the gimmick is that, like in Breath of Fire 5, you are meant to fail. And then return and succeed with better stats and knowledge gained in the previous run. If you want to save all the survivors, you need to KNOW the schedule and the areas like the back of your hand.Fantastic, but Off The Record is better.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Dead Rising 2 is the amazing sequel to the hit game for the Xbox 360 Dead Rising. you play as Chuck Greene, a motorcross sport champion who lost his wife in the vegas outbreak. He now comes to vortune city to compete in Terror is Reality to get money to get zombrex for his daughter Katey who was bitten by her mother during the vegas outbrake. This game is visually stunning when considering the release date. It adds a lot of new features just like any good sequel should. jsut like the original Dead Rising it has a very interesting story that will have you hooked by the first cutscene. Just like the original Dead Rising, it ahs multiple endings providing the player with lots of replayability. the difficulty increases as you progress through the game to ballence it out as you get powerfull the more you level up by getting pp (Player Points)The characters are fleshed out and the story is thought out. You have a reason for everything you do (well almost). you get attatched to these characters jsut like you should with a good game. There is still that classic Dead Rising random element that you can do. such as using a bench to kill a zombie while wearing a mankini. this fun random element is one of the many reasons that Dead Rising was as popular as it was when it was first released.The combat is still great with very few bugs/glitches. It makes things fun but sometimes challenging which gives a great contrast depending on your mood.Overall, Dead Rising 2 has stood the test of time and is still so much fun to play and I definitaly recommend it to everyone! I rate it 8.7/10

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												I played the original Dr on the 360, and in the usual capcom style- the game was punishing, frustrating, and highly addictive.Dead Rising 2, like it's predecessor, focuses on placing you in a zombie  infested town with lots to do and only so much time to do it. The game is very effective in creating tension, and you will often feel conflicted by the decisions you make as you will not be able to do everything DR 2 has to offer on the first playthrough.The game play is straightforward enough, you guide chuck Greene (motorcyclist extraordinaire) through a collection of zombie infested zones- each broken up by a 15 second load time, and along the way you will encounter bosses, looters, and survivors. Much of this content is optional, but you'll want to complete some of the side quests as they help Chuck level up, learn new moves, and become faster and stronger.The story of Dead Rising 2 is good, if a little uninspired. You begin  at the end of a "Terror is Reality" motorcycle show to find that fortune city is overrun by hordes of the undead. It's up to you to get chuck and his zombie infected daughter to a safe house that becomes home to you and your fellow survivors. The rest of the game's story feels more like a patchwork of cutscenes that feel like they sort of blend together, but do not feel directly linked to your actions or playstyle. Because you will only play about a third of the game'a content on a single playthrough, and because so much of that content is optional the story in Dead Rising 2 feels very loose and definitely takes a backseat to the game's truly excellent action.On my first play Dead Rising 2 took me about 15 hours to complete. And with multiple playthroughs available there is easily plenty of zombie killing value here for your dollar. This is also a well optimized port that works well on lower end graphics cards. I had no trouble playing the game on a radeon R7 240. So if you are looking for a violent, zombie-infested romp look no further- Dead Rising 2 is here on pc and it's great!

												An improvement to the first game, now with an un-restricted co-op mode, allowing a friend to play through the entire game with you.  Like the first game, a vast chunk of your leveling up is still in saving many survivors littered throughout the place.  Though the survivors are not pants-on-head ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ when following you like in the first game, certain health inflated bosses are very hard to anticipate and before you know it, you'll have rounded up 6 different survivors, only to have a boss spring out of nowhere and mow them all down on the way back to the safe zone, watching helplessly in a stun lock by Capcom's love for over-exaggerated animations that can't be inturrupted.  The true fun in the game is combining weapons to make destructive, or hilarious (or both) combinations to aid your monster mash.  Overall, a fun game with replay value, but if you really want to explore, you better be prepared to let a few of those extra survivor cases just expire.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												Dead Rising 2 is a sequel to the original 360 exclusive. It was a higher budget multiplatform release that expanded on the original game albiet not without it's own issues.Dead Rising 2 features a similar premise to the original game. You play as Chuck Greene, a survivor who has to survive for 3 days in a resort called "Fortune City". Like the original, everything is set in real time and you have a certain amount of time to complete your objectives. And depending on how well you do you can achieve different endings and even a bonus overtime mode. Fortune City is very reminiscient of the original game's Willamette mall but is more goofy and stylized after a Las Vegas casino. Chuck is perhaps the least interesting part of the game. He's mostly a dull static brick in comparison to Frank West in the original game. His only defining feature beyond his motorcycle jacket is that he has a daughter he needs to bring "Zombrex". A kind of vaccine for the virus that you must bring her every 12 hours. This concept sounds interesting but in reality it makes you feel a little stressed out because you either need to find it in really well hidden parts of the world or buy it for really enormous prices. And ontop of that return back to your safehouse at regular intervals give it to her. In general it just feels very needless and makes you wish the game brought back the original's "Infinity" mode to let you explore the resort.What Dead Rising 2 does add is the ability to craft your own weapons. Much like the original game you can find weapons out of mostly anything. As you rescue survivors and kill zombies you gain the ability to craft even more fantastical weapons. It is a legitimately interesting part to the game and does encourage actually picking up more useless items for further crafting later. They also added co-op but I generally recommend playing with a friend you can coordinate with due to the time sensitive nature of the game. Along with a time attack multiplayer mode called "Terror is Reality".In general it's a solid sequel but for all of the wacky inclusions it feels much more tedious. And because Off the Record stars Frank West, features the same content and improved several of its flaws I generally recommend it a bit more. Still it is interesting to play if only because Chuck has a nice jacket and for the differences, how small they might be.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 28, 2013
												Dead Rising 2 is an interesting game. The premise, while differing from the first one, presents the exact same kind of gameplay structure. You're thrust into a big locale filled with zombies from one end to the other, and your playground is stacked to the brim with items that you can pick up and either use as weapons or consume for health.One big problem the game has that very ironically cripples the game's fun factor is the constantly running time, with relatively strict time limits placed on every mission in the game. From what I could glean, there is no way to turn this off. Even if they don't want to abandon the intentional rushed feeling of being stuck in a city filled with zombies, the time limit could make some concessions, considering it keeps running during almost all missions, even after you've initiated them, which might leave you to randomly fail a mission that, for example, involves carrying a wounded woman back to the safe house, a trial she survives with no problems if you don't waste time running to her rescue at the beginning of the mission, but for some reason "the truth is lost forever" when you take time to make a few Painkillers and create some combo weapons beforehand and then go take her, and the timer runs out mid-mission.Another gripe is the game's limited save system. This was a huge criticism levied at the first game, and maybe the decrying of the first game was pointless, because the Dead Rising series seems poised to retain its rushed, dangerous and desolate feel of tight time limits and very sparse save points, that lead you to being unable to save a huge majority of the survivors, and make you reload earlier saves often to save time while doing the main missions.Overall, though, the game is a delight. Chuck Greene starts out as a boring alternative to Frank West, but quickly becomes endearing, especially with the addition of a good co-cast, and a sporadic, but nonetheless touching, relationship between Chuck and his daughter, who periodically needs Zombrex, medicine that keeps her from turning into a zombie, due to a zombie bite gained prior to the game's events.The combo weapons are fun, and once you get the hang of the game and start instinctually knowing where maintenance rooms are and memorizing the combinations, you'll feel naked using regular weapons (except for the firearms, and a few others, like the broadsword, which would be ridiculously fun if only it lasted for longer), which is a good sign in my opinion, because the joy of creating a cool combo weapon is satisfying to no end, especially with the discovery of some of the better ones.The psychopaths are tons of fun to fight (once you gain a few levels, 'cause in the beginning they're impossible) and have varied fighting tactics which, coupled with the different environments and weapons you have and their relatively high difficulty, provide variety in tactics that you have no choice but to experiment with to prevail.The storyline throws a few curveballs at you and doesn't throw too much monotony at you, which is more the domain of the tedious survivor rescues. Even though not too emotionally gripping for most of it, there are a few moments in the plot that can really get to you, especially if with the hardships you have to go through with so many gameplay limitations, you feel magnified emotional connections to some of the characters that you co-operate with, look after and occasionally save.All in all, there's not much to say. Chuck controls very well, and there's a certain "meatiness" to his turning and his hits (with the feeling of smashing through a crowd of zombies with a sledgehammer being my favourite), and with the exception of the annoying time limitations which sometimes don't even make logical sense and the still-annoyingly sparse save points, the game is a fun romp that makes you feel both powerful, and hopelessly weak, that controls with little fault, and oozes personality through the graphical presentation and the colourful characters.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												Dead Rising 2 is a game that drops you in the middle of a zombie infested mall, with your ability to concoct the strangest weapon in existence as your only weapon. The greatest asset of this game is the ways in which you can take the environement, and destroy hordes of zombies with it. With some of the most enjoyable weapons in games, memorable and challenging boss battles, some of the best coop gameplay I've seen in years, time management mechanics that add replayability, great controls, some nice visuals for the time of its release, a lovable Capcom style campy story and cheesy dialogue that keeps you anticipating the next one-liner, Dead Rising 2 offers hours and multiple playthroughs of fun.I'm also glad to say that the PC port is the superior version minus the lack of availability of the Case West DLC, and is actually one of the best PC ports I've played in a while. The PC controls are intuitive, the graphics are a step up from its console iterations, and the patches for the game's major issues on release (saving kicking coop partner and inability for coop partner to save progress are examples) is included.The game has its problems however, which I think are necessary to point out for the sake of the reader and potential buyer. The first is the overabundance of quick-time-events. I honestly consider QTEs to be a bad mechanic 100% of the time, due to it stripping the gameplay to, "press x to watch what happens next" or, "press x to not die." Unfortunately this game makes you go through one everytime a zombie gets his hands on you. The button prompt changes everytime, so you can't just anticipate it and get it over with quickly, luckily the prompts are always one of the movement keys or waving the mouse around. The PC port's use of Game for Windows Live is probably the PC version's second greatest flaw. Games for Windows Live is horribly unoptimized, and is a chore to use in comparison to Steam. Another issue is one I previously mentioned, the fact that the Case West DLC has not been ported, and is not available on PC, so if playing Case West is a must for you, you might want to consider getting this game for PS3 or Xbox 360, although I'd argue it isn't worth the sacrifices made for the console versions. Two very minor complaints are Chuck's slow movement speed, because sometimes I find myself getting impatient with Chuck's inability to go faster than a jog, and how New Game+ doesn't up the difficulty any. I will say however, that New Game+ is fun in the way that you can try and complete all of the missions before their timers run out, due to you being much stronger.Despite its issues, Dead Rising 2 rounds out to be a wonderful game, that I whole-heartedly recommend buying.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												Don't listen to all these silly people complaing about GFWL not working. Yes it is a discontinued system, but when installed properly there's no problems playing the game. Since saying that isn't very helpful let me break it downHere's what worked flawlessly for me on Windows 8.1 64 bit. I realize that this won't be neccesarry soon, but if you, like me, just bought it on sale for $5, you don't want to wait for this steamworks business.Uninstall (if any) games for windows live things you haveI'm fairly sure you need the legacy .NET framework installed. On win 8 hit win+x then F to get to programs and features. Then turn windows features on and offCheck all the .NET framework boxes for 3.5 and 4.5, just to be safe. I'm not sure where to find the current GFWL installer, but luckily I still have it from when I solved this trouble for one of the batman games, so I just made a shareable link from my google drive https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B9rvE1lz9fK-aFFFYUNzMm5tOE0/view?usp=sharingInstall that guyIf you don't have a xbox live account, make a free one by going to signup.live.com, make an account, then sign in to xbox.comThe game should launch no problem, you'll sign-in and put in the key, It'll need an update, do said update and restart the game. Sign in one more timeThere all better. It looks like a lot of steps but it shouldn't take more than 5-10 minutes.On to the review.Had this game for 360 and played it for hours and hours. Beat the story a dozen times, got all the endings and all that jazz. I haven't tested multiplayer on the pc version yet, but it really made the game for me on xbox. A friend of mine and I did a 12 hour straight run through, doing every side mission and such, and it was awesome. The graphics are fairly well improved from the xbox version, really it's just added anti-aliasing, but that makes it so much prettier. If you enjoy creative weaponry, killing zombies, and B horror movie story lines, then this is the game for you. Unlike many sequel type things, In my humble opinion, this series has gotten better each time. So once you're done with this one, you should absolutely buy the third game, as it is even more amazing.

												I am not marking this game as "Negative" for the game itself.  It is a fun game plain and simple.I am marking this game as "Negative" because native Controller support is gone on my system since GFWL removal, and keyboard controls are a clunky mess.Mapping the keyboard + Mouse to the gamepad with Pinnacle Game Profiler adds horrendous input lag.  Pinnacle only adds ths lag to this game and 2 others.Ever since the improperly executed removal of GFWL, which clearly was a rush-job for sure, No controller gets detected.I can't get my Logitech F-710 wireless controller or my official Xbox360 wired controller to be detected by Dead Rising 2.The last time I was able to play this game with a controller was back when it was on the GFWL DRM.  If you have a controller and think that "This game should be fun" It will not detect your controller and you will be fighting more with the Controls than the Zombies.Let the buyer beware!

												***This review is for after Steamworks took it over***Its back to the game i used to love. Nothing like dressing up in heart underwear and killing zombies with a gattling gun that shoots fireworks. Killing enemies are satisfying, though if you jump in expecting to be able to be all powerful you will be dissapointed. The begining of the game can be slow as you are, well, slow and you dont have a lot of health. Luckly levels come easy and soon youll be able to enjoy this game much more.PC Port comments: I like it. It loads fast even on a HDD. Vehical controls arent outright terrible with makes getting first place in the opening sequence a breeze. Combat is, imo, better than on console. I havnt played around with key bindins but you might want to put weapon dropping on a different button.UInlike some ports, this one supports 1920x1080 and your max refresh rate (Im assuming it can go up to 144hz if you have a monitor that supports that, but my is stuck at 60hz)Besides the issues with sound in the beginning (The game would black screen before starting due to audio quality being OVER "24 bits, 48000 Hz (Studio Quality)". To fix, go to control panel>sound and right click on the device your using and choose properties, then go to advanced and change it to the above.)Havnt tried online, but i assume it works great now that GFWL is gone. Now i hope they do the same to RE5 soon.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												There is frustration around every corner of this game.To start off, you are not welcome to play this game at your own rate. It juxtaposes a Majora's Mask-Like mechanic around a leveling system. You level up and unlock recipies and special combat moves (most of which you can more easily unlock by inviting someone who has already beaten the game to your session) But you are also required to do the main missions in the time it gives you for each of them (Which ranges between more than enough time, to just enough time, to ridiculously slim time, to a lot of time, but you have to wait until the nick of time to actually show up, and that pisses me off the most) When you die or get a Game Over, you are given the option to either return to your last save, or the less popular option to keep all levels and experience in hand, but start the story over from the beginning. You have no other option, and your last save may as well be miles behind your grinding, and this is a VERY grindy game.Next, the fairness aspect is divided between the game and the missions. They worked hard to make the zombie combat realistic and fair, however the "psychopath" bosses deal and take unreasonable amounts of damage, and you have no way of avoiding them when they attack. On top of that, bosses stick around, so when you discover them (which, at many times can be completely by accident) You have to either fight them with your current equipment and health, or wait them out until the mission requiring you to off them eventually expires. Whenever you enter the area, they will immediately hunt you down until you either beat them or leave. This flip-flop of realism completely ruins the flow of the game, if the story-save mechanic didn't do that already, as you switch between a game where proper headshots or hard hits kill zombies and Tekken with chainsaws.And I neglected to mention that this game never autosaves. You can only save it on the spot after an important mission, which at most times is near somewhere that you can save. The save mechanic revolves around visiting a restroom (this game includes a lot of sex and toilet humor, but unlike games like GTA or Borderlands, they aren't nearly as endearing, as the story goes between a drama and a horror-psycho approach), which requires precise planning allthewhile battling the clock, which is a war you will ultimately lose, as it is borderline impossible to achieve every side mission in the game with the unforgiving times they permit you.And finally, it is very buggy, you sometimes lose things you have already unlocked by going back, and there are plenty of other bugs to spare, which stick out like a sore thumb as the game is generally attractive and persistent at most times; and they aren't funny when they occur, they are just annoying, as this isn't a true sandbox game, it's a story game with a limit where every damn second counts. (Although, the levels always reset and anything you've left behind gets wiped)I am very dissapointed in this game, especially since I bought the complete pack. Besides the graphics and animation, it's really lazy with voice acting limited to story scenes and unmanageable press-a-to-continue interactions that are all labeled "interact" in-game. It's still a fun play, though repetitive, unlocking new weapons and getting through those tight zombie fending scenes and kicking♥♥♥♥♥with an overpowered combo weapon is sure a hoot; but the mechanics that top it off totally limiting what would be a fun experience into an uninteresting story with a generic traitor plot that you are forced to put before all else to avoid having to reset in said story.Unless you don't mind the restrictions to freedom and want to play an otherwise okay zombie game, I would NOT reccomend purchasing this game.

number of helpful: 24 of 45 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												It is unfortunate the series has never been able to shed the annoyance of having a time limit. Why must I play a game with time constraints?It is not necessarily a problem should there be a game mode where this can be turned off. But there's none. I know once you're done with the story the game offers a sort of unlimited game mode for the purpose of just eliminating zombies, still, I would prefer the gameplay Dead Island has. You can go around and look for lootable items and complete side missions and you can also trigger the next main story mission if you want. There are no time constraints here and everything can be done at your pace.I know there was a deliberate reason for not going ahead with this when Capcom came up with the series. It was decided with a purpose that there should be a time limit so that players cannot feel completeness - I think somewhere in a forum on the internet a guy put it right when he compared this game to the fun park experience of a child: the kid cannot really try out everything but must, instead, make a decision as to what to do and leave the rest for the future. It is all about making a priority list.So, while the game feels rushed it seems you should set a priority to the list of things you want to do. And those you fail (including a lot of side missions where you need to save people) can later on be dealt with in your next playthrough. So, yes, I really understand what they were trying to pull off, still, I did not like it.If you are not bothered by time constraints and you are OK with maximising everything throughout several playthroughs then Dead Rising 2 is clearly for you.As for me: I like taking things at my leisure so this game felt too fast-paced and I was annoyed how many side missions I failed due to not being fast enough. Dead Rising 2 is not a bad game, though! And instead of "not recommending" it I wish there was a button of neutrality but since there are only 2 options available I am inclined towards the thumbs down.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2013
												Dead rising 2 is the story of a man named Chuck Greene, a motocross superstar, who is framed by a game show host, Tyrone King. "TK" shows doctored footage of Chuck planting explosives on holding cells containing zombies. The plot of this game follows the events in the original Dead Rising, and the Xbox exclusive DLC game, Dead Rising: Case Zero. Chuck must fight his way through endless hordes of the undead, using a vast arsenal of objects used as weapons, rescue survivors, and solve the mystery of what or who began the "Fortune City" outbreak and blamed him for it. I definitely recommend this fantastic zombie survival masterpiece.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2011
												I know, I know, yet ANOTHER zombie game. I initially dismissed this game as nothing more than a poor L4D competitor, I was wrong.DR2 is a completely different game, in almost every way. You have a RPG-styled character with upgrades and perks. You have hundreds of 'weapons' you can use to annoy or wipe out zombies. The storyline isn't too bad, but if you co-op through it with some crazy costumes on the main character, it has some hilarious cutscenes.Stability wise, the game is not friendly to alt-tab, and the co-op play is also bug ridden with random disconnects. If you can stay together, it's a fun time battling missions, sharing weapons, building awesome combo weapons, driving new vehicles, and of course... killing zombies. Unfortunately, it's only a good experience about every 1 out of 3 or 4 times.If you're a single-player person, you'll find a lot to do with a good campaign, and some very, very tough bosses. If you're in it for co-op, buckle up for some fun and frustration.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2012
												Dead Rising 2 is a game that suffers greatly from being ported to PC. The graphics and technology behind the game is severely dated and it plays and looks like a game much older than it actually is. The limited options and controls that's carried over from the console game doesn't help either.The storyline is easily forgettable and the voice-acting is mediocre at best. The characters are 99% forgettable and main villain gets quickly pushed into the background by the various psychopaths wearing random costumes you will have to fight along the way.All of this is forgivable however because of the pure simple mind numbing fun of the core gameplay: Killing zombies with whichever random and illogical object is at hand. It is a simple but hugely entertaining mechanic although one that should only be taken in small doses.The game's multi-player works great as well although the fact that it uses GFWL will make it real hard to find people to play with.A good buy at a decent discount.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												First and foremost....Dead Rising 2 isn't a game that holds your hand. It can be very challenging if you are new to the game....even grueling at times. But if you stick with it....then you will eventually be rewarded for doing so. The game revolves around time and the clock is always ticking. You have to race to complete missions....help your daughter....defeat psychopaths....and in case you are wondering....there is very little chance of you actually doing everything in one play through. So you have to pick and choose your battles at first. But by the time you reach max level (50)....the game really is your own personal playground. By that point you should have the health and resources to tackle the bosses that you may have had trouble defeating before....enough money to purchase some vehicles to drive around in....and basically just explore and more importantly....have fun. Try on ridiculous outfits! Create some crazy weapon combinations! Tame an actual tiger! Just go crazy!  PROS: + Almost infinite replay value.            + Hundreds of weapons.            + Crazy costumes to unlock.            + Plenty of achievements to keep you busy. CONS: - If you are not a fan of time based missions....then look elsewhere.            - Psychopath bosses can easily decimate a novice player.             - Multiplayer for this game is almost non-existent without friends that own it.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
												Dead Rising 2 also known as Dead rising poo"return of turbo johnson""offically the best zombie game out there" - Dr PhilDead Rising 2 will take you on a adventure, full of violence and laughs. The main feature of this game is being able to use almost anything as a weapon, which it does a fairly good job at. I felt like i was actually in a mall, looking for cool things to buy. The story is pretty good, with alot of interesting boss characters. the missions felt pretty streamlined, and i didnt mind the escort ones. just a little advice, if you want to enjoy this game, you should just let katey die straight off the bat. if you get your priorities straight, this game can be really fun. In my playthrough, i played as Chunk Gren, the mentally handicapped version of Chuck Green. one of my goals in this playthrough was to barf on all of my enemies and to cover the floors of stores in vomit ( which i did).The game lets you have fun in your own ways, i will give it that. now that this game has been purged of GFWL filth, i rate it a juicy 8/10.

												This port surprisingly works very smooth. The only flaws are Terror Is Reality still being bugged and not working. My friends and me found a work around and made a guide on how to set up multiplayer ranked so others can play.The camera for the ramsterball (The hampsterball mini game in TiR) acted really funky for me and gave lots of motion sickness on my end which is rare specially since it never did on the console versions of the game. I would suggest joining a group to find others ro play or else many will decline just because lots do not change the setting to private if they wish to play solo.Remember to play co-op you need to get the radio and play through the zero chapter. Once you are in the safe room and exit for your first time via vents you will be able to invite friends.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2010
												Shopping exist all year around: maxed out credit cards, misleading "sale items", physical strain caused by excessive shopping, and dealing with other shoppers. What if I told you that you can avoid all this AND still retain all the pleasures of accessorizing? Sounds almost too good to be true. In Dead Rising 2, no one will judge what you wear: not even the characters. In fact, they'll completely ignore the fact that you're struting your stuff in your holed heart-decorated boxers. Your only competition for those new pair of suede heels are braindead corpses. Fear not, however, you can fullfill your wildest dream of finally being able to execute killing blows to those crowds you normally couldn't do anything about. Best part of this? It's a free-for-all paradise.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												Little did I know if you play this game with a friend, it tests your friendship to the greatest ♥♥♥♥ing length. Most likely, either your game or your friend's will be broken and that's just the beginning of the greatest experience. I ran around as an edgy skater kid while my friend was Davy Crockett as we beat up people with boxing gloves with bowie knives attached to them, essentially a wolverine cosplay at best. We have quite the amount of stories to tell, as my friend was blown the ♥♥♥♥ out of a map by a nerd on roller skates, we trapped a marine with PTSD into a shipping container as he threw grenades at himself, we beat up two lesbians with our edgy boxing gloves, had to go back to the start of overtime mode because I thought we could save our game after we got a USB drive, and mauled countless zombies with tricycles. Needless to say, must own and must see.

												I really love this game to death! it's an extremely worthy successor to the first game, it feels just like the first game only further in time (unlike DR3). content:
Posted: January 24
												I had not played a Dead Rising game until I pick up 2, off the record, and 3 in a pack that was on sale. I always wanted to play these games but never got around to playing them. I have to say this game does not disappoint. While this game has zombies, its more of a beat em up layered with some crafting, and leveling elements.There may be some points where zombies will catch you off guard, but there isn't anything spooky about the game. The tone is kept light and fun. I haven't fully played through the game yet, so far so good. Also, please note, that it does require some effort to get the "partially supported" controls to work but there are plenty of guides online on how to implement this. It's unlikely that the game will be patched to include controller support natively which is pretty bad form in my opinion. Either way still work picking up!

So if you have the intent on buying this game make sure you have a wired/wireless xbox360 controller. I'll give you the link to a helpful video and the link to the thing you have to download. 


YouTube™ Video: How to enable PC controller on Dead Rising 2 EASY! 

			Views: 27,786		

			www.vendfx.info/X360 (This link should work, sorry they changed the link on me!) Using a free program called X360ce PC players can now enable the game controller in the DR2 "PC Settings" page!		

 www.vendfx.info/X360 And the graphics may seem a little outdated I mean they are, but you get a steady 60fps and there isn't much to tweak with the graphics. Lot of custumizable weapons fairly decent sized map. The only way to get around fast enough is if you get the dirt bike because its practically a walking simulator at best. But you'll get the hang of it once you start playing the game. And you can't plug in any controller and expect it to work IT WON'T. That's is why I put the links for the controller support♥♥♥♥♥♥ And this is like the first semi-legit review I've typed up. So if this is helpful leave a comment. And the links work by the way. So I rate this game 8/10 because of the controller support. Update:I found this out last night. In order for the controller to work you have to uncheck native mode first and then uncheck force feed back.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												This game will supposedly coming to steamworks, so a major reason I dont recommend this game is due to the Games For Windows Live fiasco... No idea why most games didnt do the fallout 3 path adn give you a choice to use GFWL from the getgo.So after far too long figuring out and actually fixing GFWL. You have to uninstall it, reinstall, update and restart your pc 3-ish times, make sure the double security is off on your live accont which may not be what you want so use a throwaway account... and is about to be removed from all games, capcom announced they will shift their games over to steamworks.They had a sale before doing this though so headaches ahead. Ill keep this short, as for the game itself.Its okay. The combat is funny the use of everything from a sledgehammers and chainsaws to throwing hotdogs and the tables they were sitting on at enemies is good fun. However when thats the only enjoyable part of the game it gets old (even ducttaping two chansaws to the ends of a kayak paddle is only novel for so long)The problem is the odd choice of zombies being what you'd expect form a zombie game, slow lumbering and in need of dismemberment and decaptiation to kill them, to the weird human (usually psychotic) bosses you come across trying to cook the other few survivors. Fun concept but the human bosses dont work by the game rules established, you and zombies and other living people stumble, fall and react to being hit. These bosses are all on pcp and suffering early forms of madcow and run around faster than you can, do not stumble and when they do recover in an instant they hit you for insane amounts of damage where you and 20 12 gauge rounds barely dent their health.If capcom ever sells this game for a couple bucks and GFWL is gone, itll be totally worth it for the zombie bashing alone. The animations are good (capcom games tend to do this very well) Its not for everyone though, once GFWL is gone itll have a good place in history, aside from the impossible bosses, they are sidequests though so they arent required. its just not for me and likely not for a lot of people.

number of helpful: 11 of 21 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												The first couple of hours I spent with this game I was attempting to get GFWL to function correctly, so the game sort of shot itself in the foot before it was out of the gate.In general, the game has a lot of great ideas of how to have fun while surviving the zombie apocalypse, but the tone of the game never seems to suit them.  There are so many silly weapons I would love to utilize in a room full of zombies, but who has the time when you've got to find medication for your daughter and save every other nonundead human in the city?  The story's so grim, but the gameplay's so zany; and when the two are mixed, neither one is a positive experience.What the Dead Rising franchise needs is a sandbox mode:  No time pressure, and no one to save or escort or coddle, and maybe weapons that can endure more than just a handful of whacks-- Nothing but the freedom to explore and bash zombies to your heart's content.  But as it stands, the game is just a chore.

When you complete downloading it, the game asks you if you want it to run through steam. People usually say yes because thats the case with most games. BUT for this  game you have to say no. Otherwise you cannot run it through Windows for Game. Then you gotta uninstall, download it AGAIN, then say no on that previous pop up which you said yes to. The gameplay is ok at best. I found the gameplay just an average zombie kiling game. The highlight of this game is you customize your unique weapon. That gets boring after your first one. If your looking for cool way to customize your weapon, go play Borderlands or something. I haven't even touched this game after few hours of it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Probably put over 100 hours into the console version but this version beats it in so many ways! First off, mods! I love modding games, but there are amazing modders out there who have figured out how to make weapon mods (a shotgun that shoots saw blades, etc.) and other great ones like 10x the ammount of zeds in game (which ended up being too much for me because I couldn't get anywhere with out fighting through hundreds of zed.) The story continues on several years after the first DR game and focuses on a new protagonist, Chuck Green, former motocross racer, who is just trying to make enough money to get his daughter the medicine that she needs every day. Chaos ensues and the story continues and Chuck meets surivors and tries to get them back to a safehouse to await an army evacuation. There is a lot of weapon combinations to change things up in the game as well as the usual Capcom soliciting it's own games within this game (Mega Man anyone?) It's tons of gore with quite a lot of "stupid funny" moments sprinkled in. You like survivng the zombie apocalypse? Buy this game!All in all I've loved Dead Rising from the beginning, and I can't wait for September for DR3 to come to PC!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Dead Rising 2. Well, this was a ride.Let me just say it out of the bat.  It's a great game, it's fun, the characters are interesting, the gameplay is solid. It's a riot all the way. It's pretty short storywise, however the point of the game is replaying the campaign several times with better items, higher levels and trying to get all the content in the time you have alloted.This game would be easily a 9/10 for me if not for 3 things:1. It took me some time to get it to work. Several tweaks, swapping data files, etc. to get it running. Be sure to check the forums before starting the game2. GFWL. I always get a bit concerned when a game has this service for online anything. It isn't as bad in this game, since you only need to confirm once when you start the game, but still.3. Controller. This game doesn't recognize any controller besides the 360 controller. so, if you have a dualshock or any other type, it won't read it. If you can put up with those things up there, you'll get to enjoy a pretty enjoyable game.Update: Problems 1 and 2 are gone. After the steamworks update, the game doesn't require data and tweaks to run anymore and Steamworks is smooth as silk compared to GFWL old bloated overlay.Complete recommendation, get this or Off the Record when you get the chance.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 22, 2011
												Great game, it's really fun to build custom weapons. The Vegas setting is cool, the graphics are beautiful, and the gameplay can be fun. Can, that's right. I'm one of those persons that doesn't like it when you have to beat the clock. It puts pressure on me when all I want to do is kill zombies and explore. You know, in a relaxing way. You won't be exploring much, I can tell you that. Another thing I don't like are the random bosses. Don't get me wrong, I love bossfights, but I think the game should save first so you don't lose all your progress up to that point. These bosses can be very tough and frustrating and it makes me want to avoid them instead of fight them. It may seem I'm not really positive about this game, but I really, really do like it and I suggest you give it a shot if you're into zombie games and third person survival horror games.[Rating: 80/100]

												I have played Dead Rising 2 on the PS3 at least three times back in 2009 and also twice on PC a few months ago (although it was on a different account). I bought it today for my account (from Steam's Autumn sale) and since I have the latest Games For Windows Marketplace (GFWM) software already installed, everything worked fine. I did not need to adjust the settings on my sound card nor did I have to install it to the same drive that GFWM was on. I did get a window popping up which wanted to confirm the date before it decrypted the game but the message was not fully visible. I had read about this issue so was ready for it. I simply pressed the 'Enter' key to get it to decrypt. Apart from that, there were no problems. OK, so now that we've gotten the installation problems out of the way, let's talk about what the gameplay is like.Some people have complained about the time restrictive format of this game. It can be off putting at first, but once you understand how everything works, it gets less frustrating. You can see a walkthrough for this game which I am currently uploading to YouTube to see how this game should be played. Just click on my profile for more details.This game is about killing zombies while rescuing survivors of the outbreak. The story is pretty good and does continue some plot points from the first game. But the story is only secondary in my opinion because this game is all about having fun while trying to kill zombies in as many different ways as possible. I highly recommend this game and look forward to playing it again sometime in the future. I rate it 8.5/10.Anyway, thanks for reading and don't forget to like this review if you found it helpful ;-)

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												If you're wondering why i've not got any gaming hours against this game it's because I cannot play this game, It's got so many problems I've yet to make it past 6mins!I've rented Dead Rising 2 on Xbox 360 before and thoroughly enjoyed what I played. My reason to not recommend this game on PC/Steam is not because I dislike the game, I've actually been wanting to own this for years but I've been waiting until it became cheap enough on any platform to buy two copies so I can play with my partner. Well It seemed like a good deal on Steam...BUT BOY WAS I WRONG! This game is plagued with installation, client update and registration issues. Honestly just Google "Dead Rising won't start in Steam", I wish I had done this prior to purchasing TWO copies. The game doesn't launch straight off the bat, It has issues launching Microsoft Games For Windows Live (GFWL) - Which is understandable considering no manual or company actually informs you that this needs to be installed until you've purchased the game and are frantically searching the web for answers. The problems don't end there, once GFWL is installed it requires you to log in about 3-4 times over and over as it has to do multiple updates, I experienced different outcomes for each of the two copies I installed. One updated fine and then threw constant errors trying to connect to XB Live. The other computer failed to install the second update then suggested I check the error logs buried deep in my User/Appdata folder. The troubleshooting and manual fixes just keep coming beyond this point. After finally logging into GFWL I managed to start a game only to have it Crash on me in the first cutscene. This is as far as I've got, I'm frustrated having paid $20 for each copy but after the many hours I've spent troubleshooting this game before even playing it I'd be annoyed even paying $5 for such an experience. In fact I'd put money on the fact that I would probably have a smoother ride getting a pirated game to work.There is a fundimental problem plaguing PC gaming these days and if it weren't for hardcore PC gaming fans I doubt anyone would stick around and put up with this problem to support PC gaming.All thanks to Pirating there now are OODLES too many third parties involved in the licensing and registration of games now. Long gone are the days where you could just buy a game on DVD, insert the disc, type a CD Key and 15mins later DONE! The game is ready to play, with maybe the exception of a minor patch. Now days EVERY godamn company involved with the games development or distribution has to clip the ticket and request you sign up to their own Game Client Service just so they can mine your personal information and gaming habits. Now I know this is somewhat designed to stop pirating but at what cost? This makes buying a legitimate game such a slow and painful process when you have to download multiple game clients, register multiple accounts and download multiple updates. Keep this up and people WILL pirate more! What makes the whole process even more painful and flawed is that none of these Third Party services seem to actually communicate or co-operate with one another, so when one link in the chain fails they all point fingers and the poor man in the middle (US GAMERS) seeks advice or support we get shunted in the opposite direction everytime... Think about asking for a refund? Your dreaming! IT'S A JOKE!This is not an isolated issue either, it's affecting hundreds of games these days. I'm a hardcore PC Gamer, I've loved this platform for years but I'm just about OVER IT!

content:
Posted: September 18, 2011
												This game plays out in "compressed real time" and if that sounds like a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ it is.Like the previous game you have only 72 hours to survive a zombie outbreak, set in a Las Vegas style casino wonderland. You might think that slaughtering zombies in such a setting would be fun, using numerous interesting methods to kill them, and for the most part you would be correct. However trying to play the game straight only ends up feeling like punishment, as you are limited on inventory space and time, meaning you can't arm yourself without grinding out some levels.Oh and don't get me started on the boss fights. This game pulls boss battle straight out of the books of Mega Man. Forcing you into a contracted battle against big health bar bosses who can smash the crap out of you in one or two hits. If the controls were not as klunky as they are then it might be tolerable, sadly they are not.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Dead Rising 2 is an interesting title. Granted that some people will find the time element annoying, I personally find it well done and think it works. DR2 is all about killing zombies, and saving your daughter, although it is much, MUCH more free than any other game. If you wanted to, you could simply hide in a broom closet the whole game, you wouldnt get a very good ending, you wouldnt have much fun, but you can do it. Likewise, if you want to do every quest, you can go for it, although that is possibly the most stressful thing you can do.Like I stated previously, DR2 is more free than any other game, you can use whatever you want as a weapon, and you can combine things together. For instance, say you want a spiked bat, take a baseball bat and nails and put em on the workbench. Want a light sabe- sorry - laser sword? Take a flashlight and put some gems on it.sadly this game in all its humorous glory doesnt go without its fair share of glitches.granted it is rare to run into them but there have been several reports of textures not appearing, and on occasion not being able to do a missionthe guide arrow is very misleadingbut these flaws are few and far betweenthis game is a zombie killing RPG that doesn't take itself too seriously, and although it is a short review I give it my highest recommendation...9/10...thats what i would sayBUT IN ALL REALITY: I cannot recommend this game as of now. Granted it is very fun, open and enjoyable, as it turns out GFWL is shutting down next year. meaning you can no longer play TIR, and you can no longer activate it or even save. that is the most disappointing part. this is a lot of wasted potential. do not buy at all costs get it for xbox

content:

												I have played Dead Rising 2 on the PS3 at least three times back in 2009 and also twice on PC a few months ago (although it was on a different account). I bought it today for my account (from Steam's Autumn sale) and since I have the latest Games For Windows Marketplace (GFWM) software already installed, everything worked fine. I did not need to adjust the settings on my sound card nor did I have to install it to the same drive that GFWM was on. I did get a window popping up which wanted to confirm the date before it decrypted the game but the message was not fully visible. I had read about this issue so was ready for it. I simply pressed the 'Enter' key to get it to decrypt. Apart from that, there were no problems. OK, so now that we've gotten the installation problems out of the way, let's talk about what the gameplay is like.Some people have complained about the time restrictive format of this game. It can be off putting at first, but once you understand how everything works, it gets less frustrating. You can see a walkthrough for this game which I am currently uploading to YouTube to see how this game should be played. Just click on my profile for more details.This game is about killing zombies while rescuing survivors of the outbreak. The story is pretty good and does continue some plot points from the first game. But the story is only secondary in my opinion because this game is all about having fun while trying to kill zombies in as many different ways as possible. I highly recommend this game and look forward to playing it again sometime in the future. I rate it 8.5/10.Anyway, thanks for reading and don't forget to like this review if you found it helpful ;-)

												I tried playing this a couple years back and gave up, and I finally got around to picking it up only to give up again. Smashing the zombies is pretty fun, but I was overwhelmed by the time-limited missions that meant I couldn't run around and play for myself. That alone I could cope with, but the limited save slots and lack of an autosave feature or free-saving can significantly backtrack your play, despite the numerous save points nearby.All in all, it feels like a game that could have been a lot more fun if you were able to explore and pursue the story and sidequests more freely on your own time, rather than feeling like you're playing to somebody else's schedule.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												I will first start off with explaining the cons.cons-1. no auto saves/ not enough bathrooms to save inThe problem with this game is that it is huge, this makes me wonder why there is no auto save feature in this game, or at least why there aren't more bathrooms to save in. Spoiler altert... A man with a pice of glass who is way overpowered attempts to shank you in one of the bathrooms.2. Although this isn't as big as a problem as number 1, there is almost no way to find zombrex in this game without looking it up. I get that its a zombie appocalipse and you are trying to save your daughter who is infected, but why have this feature when it is almost impossible to find zombrex. The zombrex prediciment just takes away from the whole point of the game, which is killing zombies.3. you can't run, as if the developers just want to add time to the game.Pros- 1. Customization. Customization in this game is amazing. I love combining weapons and wearing different clothing, its a truely unique aspect of this game.2. Zombie killing is overall very enjoyable. Co-op with friends is even better.Overall, I give this game a 6.5/10. It's a fun game, but there are a lot of very annoying things that could have easily been fixed.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2011
												Take this as a good ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles kind of game.  It's not much of a challenge, there's a small slice of storyline, and the balance between missions and free time to ♥♥♥♥ around simply doesn't exist.... because everything is built to be "in fake-real time".  It's another Windows Live game, so don't be surprised when it doesn't validate properly, or you get connection issues.The warnings aside, it's a fairly solid game with enough entertainment value, replay time, and funny crap to warrant around $20.  Waiting for a sale below that won't hurt.  The coop is acceptable, the zombie killing is satiable (with cleverness), and seeing Playboy covers all over the place with help your brain switch gears.I recommend outright failing the story right off the bat for the first one or two runthroughs so that you can have a good amount of time in between saving survivors and killing psychopaths to get familiar with your surroundings / controls, and to kill the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of zombies for the lulz!8 / 12

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												Personal Rating: 4 of 10Before you begin judging this review do take time to read why I gave it a 4. This is a pretty decent game with tonnes of potential. To top it all, it comes with a great plot which is the only thing to keeps me playing.As you can already see, Dead Rising 2 is a zombie massacre game with seemingly illogical/nonsensical gameplay with a dash of humour. You can do cosplay, dress-up, mix and match almost anything you can find in the game to create new weapons and discover new ways to slaughter the zombies. But with all this, the plot actually comes up as rather serious and touching. Personally, I think the ridiculous dress-up (unless you buy the DLC) that comes with no purpose, spoils the mood. Imagine you are comforting your daughter dressed in a womens under garment.The gameplay, as you can already see is exactly what and as it is. Each mission, you are to butcher your way out with whatever weapon you can find laying around. The weapons degrade rather quickly so you will need to get use to what is available to you. Combining weapons can be a chore as your inventory is extremely limited and finding the right weapons to combine requires you to do a little hunting while holding on to them. Not to mention you will need to stock up on food and bonus pamphlet (seems like it) that takes up even more inventory slot. Larger weapons/props does not allow you to store them so you will need to hold on to it as your primary weapon until you find a maintenance room.Side missions will require you to fetch items, escort survivors, fight mini bosses and etc. Survivors are annoying as they can come up with ridiculous requests and they also die rather easily. Handing them weapons is a great strategy but hanging to a good weapon for them will again take up your slot. I have no issue with the AI as the path finding and combat intelligent is alright. However, boss fights, again is another chore. You simply need to find the right timed action to perform and repeat until they dies.This game solely focuses on killing zombies to the extend that they actually respawn right in front of you if you manage to clear them off in a large scale in an open area. Just like that, poof! and there appear right there. You cannot store weapons in your base when there are plenty of boxes/cupboard lying around. It is also really sad that you cannot expand or relocate your base when you can actually clear out the mall bit by bit.After a while, you will get bored and simply pushes off and avoid the zombies by travelling within the shop in the mall. I have no idea why the zombies will not spawn in the store. Maybe its because random looters will spawn in them time to time; which again makes no sense as they are yelling and breaking stuff but the zombies simply ignores them.Maybe on co-op it will give you more dynamics and options. I only manage to play the campaign and it really is annoying and frustrating rather then fun.
