number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2013
												It runs on GFWL. So GFWL haters please skip this recommendation and don't buy it.Unlike other zombie-themed games, in this game, you are NOT gonna go on a full zombie-massacre spree. Instead, you have to RUN and AVOID zombies! Which kinda sucks.The plot and gameplay is pretty boring if you're playing Single Player. Although it is considered as "Open World" game, each playthrough only lasted maximum of 4 in-game days. After 4 days, you will have to replay the whole plot again (with saved stats, like a New Game+). Also, each quest and side quests have a very limited time to complete, so if you're gonna go for the quests, you WILL run around doing errands in the entire game. Not much time to really explore.Of course, you can abandon the main quests and just do whatever exploring you want to do if you don't care about the plot and ending.Don't worry about how your character runs very slow in the game. Your running speed will increase as you level up in game. Also, don't worry about not able to beat any bosses in your first playthrough. As you level up, your attack damage will increase drastically too.If you got a co-op buddy to play with, you can have a lot of fun in this game. It has a huge variety of items that can be combined into funny and interesting weapons. Also, there are a huge variety of shop and stores you can explore. You can wear a whole lot of clothes in game, as seen on my screenshots.The online multiplayer is dead. No one play that game anymore. And the ranked match *requires* 4 players to start, so if you wanna play online multiplayer, you will need a gaming session of 4 players.My Score: 7/10 (Only worth getting if you got friends to play with)

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												I DID enjoy this game, had microsoft not decided to butt right into the middle of PC gaming. Quite frankly they should have stayed where they were with xbox. GFWL (games for windows live) is essentially another copy of steam, one however that dosent work.Heres why:-no customer support (i will go into detail later)-awful layout-dosent work (again, explained later in the recommendation)The game itself is very good as it provides a huge amount of fun when it does happen to work. my problem (if you cant tell by now) is with the enourmous cockup that capcom have provided with GFWL.After getting dead rising working on my laptop i had a good couple of hours playing on it, however...... my laptop broke a few days later. After getting my new PC, which was far better than the laptop, i decided to download dead rising for a bit of fun. Heres where the problems start - after launching it says to please log in using my games for windows live account, i enter my details and it then asks for the product key (at this point im getting confused as ive just logged in on the account that i already activated the product on) after entering my product key it says that its already been activated on another account. at this point im starting to get angry as ive just logged in, like i said, on the account that i already activated it on. after this first issue it then says that i seem to have no internet..... after this next incredably annoying problem (as i plainly do have internet at this point) it gives me an error code. finaly i think i may be able to get somewhere as to my knowledge i have a reason for why i cant log in and play the game i gave them £15 to buy. after managing to navigate their awfull website through the aid of a friend (yes, it really is that bad) i get to the customer support. Now its telling me that in order to try and solve my problems i have to talk to a representative who dosent actually work for microsoft and therefor cant help me with the issues ive had so far. He suggests to try entering my error code into their database of 'all' error codes. I put this in quotations of course because according to the database of 'all things errors' my problem turns out to not exist. By now ive spent around 3 hours just trying to get onto the game ive payed my hard earned money to get, and cant because of the terrible organisation  at microsofts end.My verdict:Pros:-good fun game with many enjoyable gameplay featuresCons:-that really is the only good point about this purchase that i can think of-the entire paragraph that i wrote :/Overall:DO NOT BUY THIS GAME - unless you know exactly what you are doing when it comes to dealing with errors from microsoft.

Now its telling me that in order to try and solve my problems i have to talk to a representative who dosent actually work for microsoft and therefor cant help me with the issues ive had so far. He suggests to try entering my error code into their database of 'all' error codes. I put this in quotations of course because according to the database of 'all things errors' my problem turns out to not exist. By now ive spent around 3 hours just trying to get onto the game ive payed my hard earned money to get, and cant because of the terrible organisation  at microsofts end.My verdict:Pros:-good fun game with many enjoyable gameplay featuresCons:-that really is the only good point about this purchase that i can think of-the entire paragraph that i wrote :/Overall:DO NOT BUY THIS GAME - unless you know exactly what you are doing when it comes to dealing with errors from microsoft.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Combining items to make new and amusing weapons is a great idea, and generally it plays well, but the game has a very annoying flaw that ruined the experience for me. The main flaw is that you are constantly on a timer, and mostly for no good reason. It means you can't just explore, create new weapons and have fun, because if the arbitrary timer runs out it's the end of the game and you have to reload, often from quite a long way back. For this reason, I would recommend Dead Island in preference to this game.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2010
												Pros:- An awesome story with great characters- A nice RPG system- Can just be plain fun killing zombies or going for achivements- Co-op brings in new life to the game- Plenty of other things to do other then trying to complete the main objectiveCons:- Combo weapons can "sometimes" break the game- At too many points, it's WAY too easy- Even after you beat it, doesn't seem to hold too great of replay-value- Stupid DLC, pay money for new moves? Should've just been in the game- No photo ability in this oneOverall:While never being able to play the original, it can still be worth it to play this game, just mucking around with it's mechanics or trying to get the achivements, can be great fun with two people playing.I'd give it a: 8.0/10Certainly could've seen some improvment here and there

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Dead Rising 2 does hordes of enemies better than any other game I've played. It's definitely an experience to leave a building and see hundreds of zombies milling about, all moving independently and all interactable. Most games only manage this number of enemies in cutscenes, not in actual gameplay. There's plenty of room to explore and experiment, and a ton of goofy weapons and skills. I'm really disappointed that there isn't a sandbox mode, but you'll make discoveries as you play through the game. A little too much time pressure, but definitely a lot of fun.Full review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2013/11/dead-rising-2.html

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												There's something to be said about the style that Keiji Inafune brings to a project.  Be it Megaman or Res Evil 4, he just knows how to make a good thing better.  Dead Rising 2 may be a his magnum opus when it comes to that.  Epic jumping high kicks, sledgehammers taped to fire axes, giant bull horns, it's a lot of fun.  Even with a relatively weak weapon like the tomahawk can you get endless amounts of fun from chopping zombies.  Food (health) is everywhere so you're never really caught short, which applies to weapons as well.  The combination system is put in very well and there's an unnerving sense hanging ofver the whole game of YOUR DAUGHTER IS GOING TO DIE GET HER SOME MEDICINE YOU MONSTER while I♥♥♥♥♥♥around Fortune City hitting zombies to the tune of Peter Gabriel's 'Sledgehammer'.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Dead Rising 2 does hordes of enemies better than any other game I've played. It's definitely an experience to leave a building and see hundreds of zombies milling about, all moving independently and all interactable. Most games only manage this number of enemies in cutscenes, not in actual gameplay. There's plenty of room to explore and experiment, and a ton of goofy weapons and skills. I'm really disappointed that there isn't a sandbox mode, but you'll make discoveries as you play through the game. A little too much time pressure, but definitely a lot of fun.Full review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2013/11/dead-rising-2.html

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												Fun game but frustrating UI. The lack of custom waypointing makes rescuing survivors a headache. I just dragged two survivors into a boss fight and now have to restart from a previous savepoint. Speaking of which, the save system is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥too.Furthermore, the grab distance to close doors and grab items is really short.It's is a very addicting game. The zombie population is huge even when compared to Left 4 Dead as they fill up the horizon for miles. They are mostly avoidable but you will end up brawling quit a bit espeically at doors where they tend to pile up. Survivors do help, move efficently and can be given weapons to dispatch zombies. There are quite a number of zany ways to deal with them. Broadsword and Baseball Bat Mace seem the most effective so far.So yeah.. fun game if you are willing to put up with some annoying issues.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
												Gave up on this! I'm not sure how many other people have had the same issues but I would recommend NOT buying any of the Dead Rising games via Steam. They're far too much of a hassle and typically require you to use the ancient version of Games for Windows Marketplace to run them (because they won't actually run via Steam). Basically a waste of money here. I've been waiting to play this particular game all week with a friend and finally we had time to play it so I had to deal with getting the game to run, then the Windows Live portion kept mucking up. After 8 computer restarts in a still optimistic attempt to continuously "update windows live" for the game (the part IN the game while the game is running) so I could actually utilize the online co-op and save my game if playing solo, that half still didn't work and I just decided to call it quits. I know there are ways to try to fix that part as well but like I said, WAY too much of a hassle for an older game, not to mention this issue has been ongoing since about 2012 (?). I like this game series for the Xbox but PC, nah. Definitely not so far.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												This game is poorly designed.  The jump kick has such a horrible delay at the end that its utterly useless.  The same goes for the dodge roll, you're frozen for a good 2 seconds before you can move.  This always results in dodging one attack and being a sitting duck for the next one.  Its horrible.  You character is so damn slow, i have 2 speed upgrades right now and he is so damn slow.  The zombies dont seem to bother the bosses much either, im getting swarmed while they stand in the middle of a group taking pot shots (slappy, those 4 redneck ♥♥♥♥ etc).  The guy in the chapel and sisters would hit me behind cover, or while im in mid vault over a wall because, again, he is slow as ♥♥♥♥.  Now you also do very little damage, i dont want to hear about replays when my laser sword looses to some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s bowie knife.  Its painfully frustrating to have to close the distance to someone shooting at you and being completely unable (without the aid of quickstep) to maneuver and dodge your way to them.  Again the dodge roll just leaves you vulnerable to a follow up attack, its useless.  There are plenty of other annoyances i face in the game and ill take the blame for my gameplay, however i find it foul how slow and immobile you are in respect to the psychos.  Its a damn shame because regardless off all of this i still enjoy the game and the series.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												I've owned this game for almost two years now, and I have only been able to play it for 5 hours.  This game says it supports an xbox 360 controller and just had a regular gamepad, i thought I found a workaround, but I was wrong.  I finally caved and bought 360 controller specifically so I can play this game today.  After two years of owning it.  Windows live wants to update.  The update stalls... every time.  So I close live and I try to play anyways.  Guess what?  The option for a controller is greyed out and disabled.  However, even if it had, it wouldn't be able to save because I'm not signed in to games for windows live...  TL;DR  If you like to kill zombies with a controller, and being able to save your progress, don't buy this game.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												Probably the weakest in the Dead Rising series....but that by no means makes it bad! This one is great, the story is a bit silly but gives you enough context to want to play on, the PC port is pretty stable and the game is a solid length. Oh yeah, and of course it is fun, of course its fun to be able to kill giant hordes of zombies with a chainsaw attached to a paddle! While the game is good, I would reccomend picking up Dead Rising 2 Off the Record instead because it is the same game only better, with more context and honestly, the game is more fun as Frank West.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												GLANCE RECOMMENDATION: 59% YES / 41% NOGOODWonderfully odd story and cast of characters.Katie's a good girl and we'll get her Zombrex dangit.Some of the combo weapons are fun to use and racking up points feels great.For the most part, the escort missions are fine. You can run ahead of them and they'll catch up well enough. Assuming they're not the limping ones.NEUTRALA plot element was introduced early on in the story, about some group sympathizing with zombies and us murdering them, but it really fell off the face of the earth quickly. Never really talked about much after the setup.The pace of this game, constantly running from one thing to the next, isn't as stressful as I thought it'd be but I would have loved a SINGLE SECOND to just explore the mall at my leisure or take a breath.BADWading through the sea of zombies is a chore and never gets any better. Every single one has the ability to grab you and make you do a floaty back slam to get them off ya. It gets absurdly worse later with the berserk zombies added into the mix.Managing inventory on the fly sucks. You'll rarely have time to just find things and prepare, unless you're letting some of the survivors die out. Add to this that some weapons will be dropped if you're hit OR you switch to other items in your bar, quickly making those ones you'd rather never bother with.Fighting psychos absolutely blows. I don't think I ever had a single enjoyable fight with a psycho. Sure their personalities and intros were fun, but the combat in this game is severely lacking finesse which makes fighting the bosses a complete nightmare. This isn't even delving into the mechanics of some that felt untouchable, so you just never fought them again, or the incredibly lengthy invincibility frames of the story last boss.SUMMARYDead Rising 2 has a strangely fun sense of humor and blood, which kept me playing, but the stiff combat and frustrating boss fights made me want to stop almost every time. This game has a slew of problems that I only pray got solved in the future iterations, because no way in hell am I playing another one of these with the same mistakes.

Posted: April 4, 2015
												This game is completely ruined by the horrible save system. The game doesn't save when you transition areas, or after cut scenes, or anyplace else except at bathrooms or at your safehouse. This means that you either spend tons of time running around looking for bathrooms to save your game, or replay the past 20-30 minutes of game every time you die. It discouraged doing anything except racing from point A to B on missions, and was infuriating every time I died. Basically, this is an open world 3rd-person zombie apoalypse game completely ruined by a horrible save system.

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												On it's own merits, as someone who is new to the Dead Rising franchise, I found this game to be unbearably dull.The game generally goes like this:Start Game -> Loading Screen -> Cutscene -> Loading Screen -> Cutscene -> Loading Screen -> Walk across corridor -> Loading Screen -> Cutscene triggered -> Loading screen -> Walk for a small amount -> Loading Screen...You get the point. It is *extremely* cutscene heavy. Furthermore, it is using Games for Windows Live, a service that will be shut down on July 1, 2014. Even if the game utilised Steam's mechanics, this game is still so painfully slow.I managed to get into the mall to find loads of zombies and some objects. I pick up the object and attack the zombies, which with the sluggish controls, doesn't help the situation either. And then I find my items deteriorate after 10(?) hits.If this sounds like your game, then go for it - I'd only give caution about Games for Windows Live. If this game seems tedious, that's because it is, and Steam offers far better zombie games from AAA developers as well as indie developers. No need to fork our your hard earned cash for this slow drivel.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												I feel like this game had two lead developers, we'll call them Tom and Lumpy. Now Tom is a reasonable guy, good head on his shoulders, and has a knack for coming up with good ideas. Lumpy was placed there because he was someone's cousin and someone owed someone else a favor. Lumpy is not a good designer. Lumpy's only talent is to uncerimoniously shart on any new idea presented such that it immediately becomes terrible. But because he's someone's cousin and someone owed someone else a favor, Lumpy gets veto power over Tom. So the two sit down at the first development meeting and I imagine the conversation going thusly:Tom: I think a more open world-style game that allows the player to explore and roam at will through a large area would work best. We can make it a casino, that way there's plenty to do and look at.Lumpy: Perfect! We can break everything up into chunks that take forever to get through unless you run and miss most everything interesting!Tom: Erm...ok, so as far as story, let's have the plot revolve around the main character's daughter. They've developed a cure but she has to keep taking it. Lumpy: Great! We can attach it to a timed mechanic that means you have to sprint through the complex and sprawling levels to get back to her to give her medicine or else she dies and the game instantly ends.Tom: Ummm...I guess. I was also thinking we could do the custom weapons thing again. See what kind of crazy things players will come up with.Lumpy: I love it! Then we'll make these weapons super fragile so they break near immediately and the components are hard to get so you don't get to use them hardly ever and the rest of the time you just have to wail on zombies with whatever is handy!Tom: *sigh* Ok, ok, ok. The main character is a reporter, so let's include a kind of photography system. Adds a new dimmension to game play and opens up a lot of avenues for sharable content and humor.Lumpy: Brilliant! We can force that to be a core part of gameplay and jerk the player out of the action and tension with unnecessarily long animations and grading screens!Tom (who by now is close to tears): I...I guess we can do that...but we need something to add some tension to the game. The daughter thing is good but some overarching tension in terms of the surroundings would be great.Lumpy: I know! Let's have the whole game run on a timer so that you have to race through and miss most of the cool stuff before the time runs out or you automatically die! And it'll mean people have to replay the game over and over again!Tom: ...I hate you so much right now.That's about the formula for the game; take one good idea and smash it to death with bad ones until you find yourself sobbing at your desk asking the game gods why and wishing dearly to be able to get this game out of your library.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												Dead Rising 2 is an open world zombie survival game, with nudge of humor.You are Chuck Green, you take part in a game called Terror is Reality, where the aim is to drive around on a motorcycle killing as many zombies as possible to win a cash prize. The money goes to his daughter, who has the "infection" that, if untreated, leads to her becoming a zombie.Once again, like in Dead Rising, you are in a mall, trying to find survivors and ocasionally running into psychopaths that need to get their head smashed in. This is also where the nudge of humor comes in, these psychopaths are often hysterical and over the top, making it that much more fun to kill them. The open-world offers allot of space for looking around and looting, don't forget to find Zombrex for your daughter along the way.The game also offers online co-op mode in which both players, play as Chuck. Only the host will be able to save the game, but you keep all experience and items throughout the game. There are multiple different endings and all are worth checking out.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												A friend and I go this game just looking to ♥♥♥♥ about a bit and kill zombies in fun and entertaining ways, and there are tons of hilarious, inventive ways to do that. But the game doesn't want to let you mess around and jave fun. All of the missions are on time limits, which means you'd better get going or else you'll fail and have to reload a save from half an hour ago, 'cause there are no save stations anywhere. Comnime that with the fact that you can only take 4 hits until you level up, and   even then, you only gain one more hit per level, it's hard to just go around wreaking havoc, and it just seems easier to walk around the zombies. Except that the character doesn't control very well and there is a severe lack of a sprint button. The game that I am describing may be what you want, but it isn't what I thought it was going to be.

content:

												Wtf is wrong with all the people who are saying this game is bad? This game is AWESOME!!!There is so much things to do in a fairly big map: thousands of items to discover, plenty of side missions, side bosses, combining items to make new weapons, mixing drinks to create potions, secret areas, shortcuts, combos, minigames, reading magazines to boost your status and much more! Oh, and don't forget the very well made coop that lets you enter in your friends game at any time with your character.There is absolutely no reason to complain about the game itself. I agree that the first one is better, but this one is amazing as well.And about the DRM thing... yes, it's a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ but is working (for me at least, using win7). Just keep trying to reconnect that it will connect eventually.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												I had never played Dead Rising 1 as it was not on PC. I was very into L4D2 logging over 200 hours into it. I had expected Dead Rising 2 to be in the vain of L4D but in third person and whole lot more zombies. Instead I got an open world zombie game with slow pacing, long grind, clunky combat and unbalanced boss fights.Pros:Runs well on a AMD Phenom II X4 940, 2GB DDR2 and GTX 670. Sometimes under 60fps.Cons:-Huge grind. As described below about boss fights, you need to level up in order for boss fights to be fair. I am at level 20 and boss fights are still not balanced at all. Avoiding boss fights can be futile at times as described below.-No running. You walk faster by levelling up. Levelling up auto assigns attributes (attack, speed, life etc..) so their is no customization. I am currently at level 20 and still walk very slow.-Time based gameplay, all missions are based on a certain time, the absence of running really adds frustration to this as you cannot get to some missions in time, especially story missions that forces you to load from a user savepoint which could be 30 mins back.-Save points are limited to "restrooms", if you can find them and remember to do so. Current game design is that after every mission the game should auto-save. Not with Dead Rising 2, if you had beaten a hard fought boss, you must remember to find a restroom ASAP. Even then, you could be low on health after this boss fight and die on the way to a restroom.-Numerous boss fights that are unbalanced. You need to be leveled up and on a 2nd playthrough in order for the boss fights to be fair. These boss fights show up in your missions list and you have to assume from the mission description that you will fighting someone, it doesn't tell you outright. I essentially have to read, thnk and pick rescue type missions in order for me to level up so when I do encounter bosses, it will be more fair but so far still unbalanced. Even if you intend to avoid boss fights, some missions force you to go into a certain area which will trigger a boss fight, and because you walk so slowly, it is difficult to evade the boss fight after

content:
Posted: October 15, 2013
												I got this on sale for $5 and what a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ god damned waste of money it is. And that's coming from a HUGE zombie game fan. The save/reload system is horrible: you die once and it's game over, back to the title screen and reload save, and sometimes you can be very ♥♥♥♥ing far from a save area. It's a horrible save system that does not fit the feel of the game at all. And the biggest issue, you are always on a timed main mission meaning you constantly feel rushed to get the dezombifying medicine to your daughter so you can't really enjoy anything else the game has to offer often enough because you always have a rushed feeling. And the game just feels mediocre. It has that "SEGA arcade" crap look and feel.Shove this game up your♥♥♥♥♥10DR3 is really good though because they actually did it right.

DEADRISING 2 = MY SECOND FAVE ZOMBIE GAMEgod knows how many hours i have on this, i have played it a total of three times (nonsteam copy, ps3 and steam) and its amazing, comedy spiced with zombies = MAYHEM also i wont spoil the story, the games too good for that :P +PROS+ZOMBIES EVERYWHERE :DDD+Combining weapons (NOT IN DR1)+story and characters+cool outfits (besides some that make chuck look like a tranny)+nice dlc (not like some games that force it upon you but its some nice unique clothing items :P)+game is not the same as the first but has inproved on it, takes place in a diffrent place also+mods, if you know where to look. -CONS-a bit laggy (least for me)-clothing that make chuck look like a♥♥♥♥♥ least theres not many lel-being timed (and thats all, the cons wont stop me playing though since the game runs good most the time and is awesome)

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30
												I haven't played this game for a couple years, but it left enough of an impression that I think I can write up a quick review.My short review is: Look at (and probably buy) the standalone Dead Rising 2: Off the Record instead.Chuck Greene is the protagonist for this game, and he's the most bland protagonist I've ever seen. The protagonists in Pokemon games are deeper than him, and that's nearly impossible to accomplish. On the flipside, I've played someone's copy of Off the Record and bringing Frank West back was the best idea ever. In comparison, Frank West is far more self-centered than Chuck Greene, but that just means he's got way more depth.Next up, DRM. Last I checked, DR2 uses the old Games for Windows Live which is now defunct. Apparently Microsoft decided they couldn't monetize their DRM, so they abandoned it and left it questionably functional on newer Windows operating systems.There's a new Games for Windows Live that goes under a new name I've forgotten (new name + same thing = cash? who does Microsoft hire to make stupid decisions like this?), but it's completely new and incompatible with older games. Either way, some games with the old GfWL sort of work right, apparently Dead Rising 2 does most of the time, and others don't, which is why you no longer see Fable 3 in the Steam catalogue since that broke with the abandonment of GfWL.In other words, BUY AT YOUR OWN RISK. The DRM was trash to begin with, and never got replaced when Microsoft finally put it in the trash bin where it belonged.The Off the Record version of this game would've been a good timeless classic, but the Microsoft DRM takes the 'timeless' out of it. That DRM has been a ticking timebomb since DR2's release.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												So, things are better now that Steam has worked with the publisher to move the saves over to Steamworks.  Kudos to Steam for helping make that change.  I'm absolutely certain that this will return some good will for people who felt ripped off that they'd paid for an unplayable game (BTW...doing the same for other GFWL titles, would be great).  I know that it made me feel a lot better about Steam's response to the problem, especially as a very long-time Steam member.As for the game itself, I'm still pretty torn and can't wholly recommend it on PC.  It's a fairly clunky port from consoles, and honestly it probably plays better on those (which pains those of us who are PC gamers).  The save system is still very console-focused and pretty annoying, as a lot of checkpoints are set in an area where there is a high potential of death, and then you're stuck replaying quite a bit just to take another run at the same thing.The reality is that other zombie titles play much better on PC...Left For Dead 1/2, Dead Island, etc.  If you've blasted through all of those and simply need another zombie killing game on your PC and this is on sale (like it currently is), then it's perhaps still worth it.  Otherwise, move on to stronger titles or at least wait until this one is on sale.  I the meantime, I reluctantly can't give the game a recommendation, even though it's decent.  I'd probably give it a thumbs-up on a console.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												This game has been left to die. However, I will not leave you to die. If you follow these steps, and are focused and determined, the game should work for you, for a while.How to fix Games for Windows Live on Windows 8 Pro x64Ironic Fact: GFWL doesn’t really work with Windows 8 Pro x64.Good Fact: it’s not that difficult to fix.If GFWL isn’t working for you (best way to check is play a GFWL game and see if you can bring up the home menu. If not, it’s broken) here’s what to do.NOTE: YOU MUST MUST MUST DO THESE STEPS EXACTLY. DON’T SKIP ON REBOOTING OR ANYTHING. ALSO MAKE SURE TO DOWNLOAD THE FILE I’VE LINKED TO, AND NOT ANY OTHER VERSION OF GFWL.1\ uninstall both “Microsoft Games for Windows - LIVE Redistributable” AND “Microsoft Games for Windows Marketplace”2\ reboot3\ download the GFWL installer from http://www.xbox.com/en-US/LIVE/PC/DownloadClient4\ IMPORTANT: Right click the above installer, go to properties and change its compatibility to “Windows 7”. Save and exit.5\ IMPORTANT: Right click the installer, and choose “Run as administrator”6\ After it’s installed, run the GFWL game again. It should now work fine and redownload your profile.Steps 4 and 5 are really, REALLY, REALLY important.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2010
												This game is hours of zombie killing fun. I have never laughed so hard playing a video game than my experience playing Dead Rising 2. If the silly costumes, revolting kill combos, or running zombies over with a Hummer isn't enough, invite your friend to join your game and team up for even more laughs. In addition to the story mode with a high replay value, there's a versus mode that pits you against 3 other players online to kill zombies in 9 different types of gladiator style games. $40 is a small price to pay for an easy 80 hours of zombie killing enjoyment! If you like Left4Dead or any zombie movies, you'll love Dead Rising 2.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												I bought this game on sale expecting to have a hilarious adventure of building nonsense weapons to kill Zombies.What I got was the worst controlling game I have ever played in my life. Chuck moves at about the pace of a snail, even with levelups your speed never improves beyond "A brisk walk". When you attack, you are automatically locked into the slowest windup animation for an attack I have ever seen. You want to stop attacking? Nope. You have to commit to every single attack you make, and are usually locked into your three hit combo. Is the boss attacking and you're still attacking? Prepare to get hit, prepare to take damage. Constantly.Oh you want to dodge cancel? ♥♥♥♥ you. Dead Rising 2 does not want you to be fast or have fun, you want to cancel any sort of movement? Impossible. Want to dodge out of your attack animation? Impossible. I've been told there's a dodge roll move in this game, and maybe that would allievate the terrible controls, but you only get it by leveling up. Randomly. I hit level 26 and still haven't gotten the privelege of actually unlocking it. Who knows, maybe you could actually cancel out of your movements instead of being locked into a horrifically long animation? I doubt it though.The plot is pretty barebones and is mostly just an excuse for you to go kill Zombies in a fantastic environment. It's not nearly as fun as advertised. You can combine weapons you find around Fortune City to make new weapons that are by default, just 100x more useful than anything you can pick up. They also give far more PP than standard weapons. There's a wide variety of them too, but you'll only use about three. Most of them are just gimick items used to pad out the system, while only a few are actually consistently useful and reliable. Mostly the Laser Sword.You can also rescue survivors for bonus PP. That's about all there is to that thing. They have terrible AI, will constantly get grappled, and can't fight worth a potato.But there are also boss fights you can randomly encounter! Such hilarious and creative boss battles such as "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off Mail Man", "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off Mall Cop", "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off Biker", and my personal favorite "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off Chef". They're all relatively frustrating because of the controls, and if they catch you off guard, you're ♥♥♥♥ed. You have to pre-plan every boss fight, save beforehand, come equipped with the best weapons you can make, at least three healing items, and even then you're pretty much screwed due to their invincibility phases, FAR faster than you speed, and the fact their attacks don't take a year to wind up. Most of them do have small phases where they're vulnerable, and you'll get in maybe two hits before they remember that you're not supposed to be having fun and stun you.Also nearly all the characters are either shallow stereotypes, or annoying. The boss fight against the weird Lesbian Ninja Girls comes to mind. They feel the need to constantly remind you that you are a pathetic man, and that they have boobs, and are not going to sex you. It's not nearly as interesting as it sounds. All in all, there are far better ways to spend your money. But this review is many years late so you've probably already bought it.

number of helpful: 3 of 10 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												Want a real review?  Keep scrolling, because this is a port rant.  No, it's not just GFWL, calm down.Even with GFWL gone, this port is dreadful.  While the game itself is definitely worth the asking price, I can't recommend it unless you love super-cinematic 15 FPS at random times, along with several pathetic issues that ruin it for you.First off, one of my smaller annoyances.  The textures are horrendous.  I don't mean "old-looking" horrendous, I mean that they look like crippled and downscaled versions of textures, like they're rendering in 1/4 res or something.  I sincerely doubt that these are the textures they made-- it's probably just the downscaled versions of the textures that they used for Xb360/PS3.  I wouldn't complain, had performance actually been somewhat decent.Regardless of your framecap (which is nicely placed at 120FPS... we're making progress, Capcom) Cinematics also seem to be at-- you guessed it-- "cinematic" 30 FPS.  Want to hear something even worse?  In both cutscenes AND gameplay, your mouse cursor will just appear at random times!  I've even tried alt-tabbing out and restarting the game, but no, it's just the port!  It's got THAT little effort behind it!The controls are a bit all over the place.  C for the Transponder, T for your watch, and a million other stupid binds that anyone could have placed better.  It's another small complaint, but definitely worth mentioning.I find with MSi Afterburner's overlay enabled that RAM usage will never go over 2GB, only 300MB max will be used of my 3GB R9 280 (usually hovering around 30% usage with max settings), and the CPU will just tank performance at random times-- yes, even during cutscenes and in the shelter, where NOTHING should be that taxing, I'm getting 100%/99% usage for my cores.The port woes make this game unenjoyable.  Avoid it, unless you've got enough processing power to brute-force it.  Even then, you're not missing out on much.  Capcom is a joke, and I highly suggest avoiding their products as nothing they release has been even half decent on PC.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												It's an improvement over DR1, that's for sure... The survivor A.I. is much better scripted, the layout of the map isn't nearly as obnoxious as it was in the original either... Also, the timer is a lot more mangable and if you follow a survivor rescuing guide you'll realize how much Capcom actually spoon feeds us the survivors this time around... In DR1 it was a disaster to have to guide back more than a couple people, in DR2, it's embraced... the larger the group, the more survivability it has.I found Chuck to be a lot more stoic and bad♥♥♥♥♥than Frank West and I assume that's what they were going for but playing this after playing DR2: OTR, you realize how much of a blank slate Chuck really is... almost downright boring to watch... but before that little mistake happened, he was just a total bad♥♥♥♥♥My only gripe is that there's little to no reason to head in to the underground tunnel section of the game and I remember that being one of the most terrifying things about DR1... is that you were essentially forced down there for a lot of reasons... you briefly skim part of it this time around. Also there's a plethora of combo cards in this game and unfortunately 95% of them are novelty gag's or downright worthless. The easiest and earliest combo weapons you can make are among the best in the game, which leaves you little to nothing to look forward to.The game is much more fair than DR1 which is a great and bad thing all at once. The problem with making things fair in a survival horror game is that it takes away a lot of the fear you'd normally have playing it... Although in this game's defense, you can't really begin to play it seriously until you hit level 50... Trying to accomplish anything profound before level 40 and you're basically zombie fodder. So it's a bit of a grind out...

												Homemade Tortilla (for 8 servings)Prep : 30 minsCook : 25 minsIngredients :- 1 3/4 cups all-purpose flour- 3/4 teaspoon salt- 1/4 teaspoon baking powder- 1/4 cup vegetable shortening- 1/2 cup hot waterDirections :1. Whisk flour, salt, and baking powder together in a large bowl. Add vegetable shortening and work into flour mixture using a pastry cutter until it resembles coarse crumbs.2. Form a well in the middle of flour mixture and mix in hot water. Work flour and water mixture together with a fork and transfer to a cutting board.3. Knead until a smooth, soft dough is formed, about 3 minutes. Add more flour if dough is too sticky.4. Place more flour on cutting board, cover dough with bowl, and let rest for 15 minutes.5. Cut ball of dough into eight equal parts and cover until needed.6. Roll out balls of dough either by hand or with a tortilla press.7. Heat a large skillet over medium-high heat. Place flattened tortilla in skillet and cook until it begins to bubble, about 1 minute. Flip tortilla over and cook for an additional minute. Flip again and cook for 1 more minute. Repeat with remaining dough.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
 Disclaimer - I do not own Dead Rising 2, I have played the game via Steam family share.Dead Rising 2 is an open world survival horror beat 'em up game which was released in mid 2010 on both console and PC. You play as Chuck Green, who is a motocross rider, as you try to survive a zombie outbreak. The game is set in a shopping and casino complex which is filled with zombies. You encounter up human survivors throughout the game, as well as finding and crafting weapons. Game play wise; Dead Rising 2 is a very typical hack and slash style. You find weapons around the levels such as crowbars, sledge hammers, pistols, right the way up to silly items such as garden rakes and party hats.  As you progress through the story you get more experience  points from completing missions and saving survivors. The game is also heavily based around time constraints too; you have to do missions at certain times; if you miss the time you either loose the game or the mission is gone and you can never finish it. This to me made me have to make a lot of sacrifices to what content I actually got to see; I personally didn't see a huge need to have the time constraints in place as you just end up missing out on content that the developers have worked hard to make.That being said; all of the missions and side quests are virtually all the same. Side missions consist of finding the survivor, and escorting them back to your safe house. Whilst main story missions are "walk here" and "kill that" goals. To me the lack of creativity really felt like it let the game down here. Graphics wise; Dead Rising 2 is a game which has been out for close to five years now. Whilst at a glance the graphics look OK, but if you get a closer look you can really tell the age of this title. Poor quality textures are the main culprit here. I can sort of forgive it as it is an open-world game though. The main story right up to the ending had me intrigued the whole way through. Although some of the plot twists are kind of predictable if you pay attention; it was still enough to keep me interested. Sadly though the ending of the game really annoyed me. I don't want to spoil it for people but it kind of had an anticlimax feel to it which didn't leave a nice taste in my mouth afterwards.Dead Rising 2 isn't exactly a difficult game, there are a couple QTE type actions you have to carry out when you are grabbed by a zombie, but personally I found the most difficult aspect of the game was to be finding weapons which don't completely break from durability loss after a couple of hits. Ammo for guns is few and far between so the majority of the time you are in melee - so ideally you need a couple of melee weapons each mission due to them breaking all the time. Towards the end of the game, if you managed to rescue a couple of survivors, you really do become quite overpowered; once my speed skill was maxed out I was able to dodge most  zombies when running between objectives. Boss fights are pretty "meh" too; none of them have any real difference, they all tend to be just a regular enemy but with more health. I did find the fight with the helicopter to be quite interesting but that was the only real original boss fight concept in the game. Each zone/level is pretty hectic, like I said, you can have up to 7000 zombies on your screen at any time, there are an abundance of items to pick up and craft into different weapons, not to mention lots of little Easter eggs to find, such as playing a golf simulator. The atmosphere in each of the levels actually really reminded me of Las Vegas; and if you have been there it will really feel like you are there in the game (even though you aren't there location wise in the story).A full playthrough of Dead Rising 2 with the majority of side quests being completed, took me just over ten hours. I personally cannot see any reason why I would play through the single player story again as it's very linear and you cannot change the events that take place. The multiplayer is also pretty derelict too - at the time of writing this, there are only 40 people in the game.Technically I didn't have major game breaking issues; just a small gripe with the crazy amount of loading screens this game has. Literally every couple of minutes you get a loading screen, whether it be for a cut scene, ending of a cut scene, changing zone, I counted 7 loading screens in the space of 10 minutes at one point. For me, that is unacceptable and I am surprised not many people actually picked up on it. In conclusion; do I recommend Dead Rising 2? Personally I wouldn't recommend it at full price. For starters there are much better zombie games like this out there in the form of Dead Island. The game's length is too short for me - and all this being compounded by lack of multiplayer activity just makes this a single player game. So I cannot recommend Dead Rising 2 at full price; if you can get it for at least 50% off, you may as well pick it up as it's an OK open world title, but nothing more.  Tom's Score Card1) Stay away2) Only recommended when on sale3) Recommended4) Highly recommended5) This is a must playIf you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

content:
Posted: November 4, 2012
												Welcome fellow ZOMBIE hunters to Dead Rising, 2. In this adventure you play as protagonist, motocross champion Charles Greene who prefers to be called chuck. Chuck participates in controversial games called “Terror is Reality” in Fortune City, Nevada in hopes to win prize money to buy a drug called Zombrex which needs to be administered every 24 hours to young and out of place daughter, Katey. If she does not receive her injection she dies and turns into a ZOMBIE. Right after the 1st tournament a horde of ZOMBIES get loose all over the city & Chuck is forced into a position to search for Zombrex. During this time he’ll come across other survivors to rescue & psychopaths to defeat. & all along the way must survive himself an overwhelming amount of Undead ZOMBIES. Single player or Co-Op, you’ll be able to play thru again after the end to continue leveling and gain new weapons and combo weapons. The game offers a large range of individual stories and is very violent and dangerous.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2013
												The sequel to the million-plus selling Dead Rising, Dead Rising 2 takes the zombie survival horror to Fortune City, America’s latest and greatest entertainment playground. Featuring a new story, two online multiplayer modes (2-player co-op campaign and a 4-player “TV show” themed Pay-Per-View event that pits humans against zombies), thousands of on-screen zombies and more, Dead Rising 2 takes zombie survival horror to a whole new level. As Chuck Greene, you have 72 hours to save your infected daughter, clear your name and survive the hordes of hungry zombies before the military comes in and nukes the city. To ensure your survival, you can combine everyday objects to create numerous deadly combo weapons and slaughter the ravenous zombies. Dead Rising 2, it’s where Creativity Kills.

This Game taunts you from before you've even begin to purchase it, beware local shoppers! oooooooOOOOOOOoooooo This is my experience of the Dead Rising Poorly ported PC version.. I'm sad to say that the game should have been left on consoles with its original brethren. The Experience: Zomies stutter across the screen and do not stop moving, your character also stutters as the frame rate also dips in and out. about because of the poor decision of Capcom and their poor porting abilities. As said before this game taunts you before you've even picked it up because Steam recognizes the game for "Full Controller Support". In order to become one lucky participant for Full Controller Support You'll need:1) Microsoft Branded controller... or  2)A Microsoft Branded Controller. Oh you can use Pinnacle Game Profiler, you say? Sure Go ahead.. your avatar is going to jog and then forced to a halt every 2 to 5 secs that you decide that you want to hurry to your destination.Whats that you say? You don't need to run in a zombie apocalypse?? Name the last person who lived in a zombie apocalypse that didn't run. Don't worry, I'll wait....ok you done? Yeah AVOID this game on Steam at all costs. Even avoid it on sale.Ok so I did find 1 pro: Never have I ever seen a Zombie suffer with Dyskinesia so beautifully Pro: Beautiful Uncontrollable Moving ZombiesAverage: VisualsCon: Controls (the game was awfully ported, its like a monkey ported the game or something)Frame rate Randomly dips from 30 to 12 for no apparent reason.

												Previously, I had a very bad rating for this game. You will stumble upon many weapons to aid you in this game, I have NOT played until the final ending, so I will not jump into conclusions.You will be able to craft weapons, for example, you can put a wooden bat and some nails, to make it a spiked bat. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2, 2011
												Excellent mindless fun. Butcher zombies with anything you can find lying around, or tape shizz together and unleash hell with combo weapons (I recommend the electric chair :-P). Excellent storyline with a fair amount of twists and turns. There's an extended/alternate "Overtime" ending which only occurs if certain choices are made during the story. You don't even have to play the story, you can just spend your time chopping up rotten zombies and level up for when you restart the story. All key items and your level is transferred over when you restart the story which is a massive bonus in my opinion. You don't need to have played DR1 to enjoy this title.8/10

Posted: February 21, 2014
												A pretty bad port of the console version.The game itself was awesome and I had a blast with it.However even though it was developed primarily for consoles, it has no controller support for windows, and the keys can't be changed without editing some config files.Also for some people apparently the volume is stuck low and the only way to make it louder is to crank your speakers, which can be a problem for headphone users.It has a coop mode that still has the odd person around to play with, although everyone I managed to play with was kind of laggy.I'm sad that Capcom won't rerelease it without GFWL, but considering how lazy of a port it was, I totally understand their position.Play it while you still can!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 7, 2013
												Dead Rising 2 keeps the feel of the original while expanding the size of the map and looking much prettier. That's both good and bad; boss battles are still sprung on you unfairly and are incredibly annoying and frustrating, you'll still lose vast swathes of progress when you forget to go to the bathroom, and you're still going to be tearing your hair out on your first playthrough (especially if you want to save everyone). But it's the same good zombie fun, captures the original's feel very well, and expands on it with new content and features, more zombies, a bigger mall, lots of secrets to uncover, and multiplayer. Well worth the buy, especially if you've got a nice computer. (I've actually played way more hours than it shows, but it doesn't work for me on Steam.)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												Dead Rising 2 is a really fun crazy enjoyable game that has a "meh" port.The story is ridiculous and not really something to be taken seriously. The characters are all overplayed cliches, but that suites dead rising just fine.Combat is fun button mashy goodness it's basically teh whole reason you play the game to kill zombies with wacky unconventional weapons. The "maniac" bosses are give and take some can be extremely frustrating and by  the last few hours of the game a new zombie is added in that makes the last few hours less fun.Graphics are where the port fails Textures were meh and frames werent great but there are a large number of zombies on screen.In teh end the port didn't detract from my enjoyment but some of the bosses did and the super strong zombies at the end of the game make combat extremely frustrating I found myself avoiding it in general. So in teh end I do recommend Dead Rising 2 it's a fun game with some flaws.

None of that  fast moving zombie garbage.Good story, lots of fun and funny missions.Capcom did a terrible job of porting it to the PC though.  You are more or less stuck with the default control scheme, there is no way to re-bind the keys inside the game.  You can hack an INI file to change the bindings but it's a little buggy.  Even after changing all of the "move forward" commands in the INI when pushing a cart I have to use the default "W" key.  Likewise, the on-screen prompts will still use the default key which can make it difficult to figure out which one you really need to push for quick-time events.You can use a gamepad, but the ONLY one that works is a XBOX 360 wired controller, any other gamepad including the wireless XBOX 360 controller won't work.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
Dumb & simple zombie killing fun. Like the first game, weapons and health are generally all around you only this time around you can combine two specific items to make another weapon that's possibly cooler, sillier, practical, or a combination of a number of those. You can find out what item goes with what via Combo Cards which are unlocked through general progression of the game such as examining certain posters, leveling, defeating psychopaths, etc. You can combine items without the specific card however the item produced won't be as effective and rewarding. It's highly encouraging to produce the Combo Weapons because using them generally nets you PP for leveling and curiosity in how they'll work will become pretty high.You're free to run around the world as you please (aside from some areas that can only unlocked from doing certain missions) though its criticized time limit makes a return so you only have so much time to get to doing the missions. If you stick to doing missions, not be as distracted, and perhaps if you're at a decent level it won't feel like it's rushing you to go do something so much. Even if you fail a task no matter how important and until the timer runs out or you choose to restart the story you're free to run around freely doing whatever. Restarting the specific save file's story allows you to keep your level, money, and Combo Cards for that next playthrough.The plot & dialogue is full of cheese, especially with the psychopaths. I think it's for the better that that's the case.There isn't much depth to the actual zombie killing aside from just having good weapons for the situation and the psychopath fights. The psychopaths can be extremely cheap in their own special way but at least for most of the fights you're free to leave and return to the area in case you don't feel ready for the boss fight. The co-op's overall doable. A bit easier (if no lag is present) but adds enjoyment to the game. The money and level you've earned anywhere in a save file can be used in both single player and co-op where the only thing that doesn't carry over for either is the story if you're not hosting the game. The entire thing could have probably used an implemented in-game chat and give-item-to-partner feature as opposed to dropping or chucking the item for them to pick it up.Fetch quests, escorts, and just messing around. Probably better with a controller since keys are unrebindable.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												One of my favourite zombie games of all time, alongside the Resident Evil series. Played this on the Xbox 360, but since I prefer computers to consoles now, why not download it on  The game play is fun, bloody and fluid. There are tons of weapons, custom and normal, to find and use on the undead. And on the plus side, the survivor AI is improved and much better than the original Dead Rising (please get a PC release!) The main problems however is the story, launch problems and the voice acting. The story, compared to Dead Rising 1, is kinda crap and lacks the seriousness of the first game. Voice acting can be pretty crap in sections and everyone, despite the fact its meant to be in Nevada, sounds Canadian (I have no quarrells with Canada or Canadians, I have massive respect to the country, as well as family connections). And finally, the launch issues. For some reason, this game will not launch if you have a Windows 8 operating system. But no worries. My trick is to do to your Steam directory, go the SteamApps file, click on Common, right click on Dead Rising 2 exe. and then set the compatibility to Windows 8. Works for me.Overall, this game is fun and brilliant to play. However, this and the third game is not as fantastic as Dead Rising 1(Please get a ♥♥♥♥ing PC release! My day would be complete then!)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												Dead Rising 2 is easily high-ranked on my top 10 games of all time. This game is so much fun! Kicking zombies butts with knifes attached to boxing gloves, in a big♥♥♥♥♥shopping mall is truly f**** amazing. The combo weapons are one of the main new features in this installment. Crazy combinations like a Power Drill+ Spear , Wheelchair+ Battery or even  SquirtGun+ Gasoline can cause total DESTRUCTION! But Sadly, the combinations are limited. You can see the different combinations by collecting combo cards, wich can be acquired by leveling up and many other ways. Despite the awesome gameplay, the story is also kinda great. You play as Chuck Greeene, a motocross champion who came with his  bitten daughter Katey, to Fortune City( a mix of shopping malls and casinos ) to participate in a reality tv show called ''Terror Is Reality'', in order to win some money to buy his daughter some doses of the highly expensive Zombrex. Then sudddenly, Zombies from the show are released, causing an outbreak in Fortune City. And if things werent bad enough, Chuck is claimed  by the medias, ''responsible'' for causing the outbreak. So basically the main goal of the story is to clear your name and escape Fortune City. One of the good things about this game, is that you are not in obligation to follow the story. This is great for younger players who wants to mess around and have some fun killing the zombies. However, one thing I dont like about Dead Rising 2 is the psychopaths/bosses. Some of them like the chef, are way too hard to defeat when you are low level and dont know the game very well. In my opinion, the most easy and proper way to defeat them, is by grabbing one or two snipers, a couple of orange juice/lobster and some magazines that increases the damage you inflict with guns. That is just boring for a boss battle. In  conclusion, if you are new to Deadrising , get this game. And if you are already familiar with the franchise, get Off The Record. In this version of DeadRising 2, Frank West ( Hero of the first Deadrising), is the main protagonist. The game also includes a Sandbox mode. A mode where you have no objectives and can do whatever you want! So go check it out! I rate DR2 8/10 for its zombie killing madness.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												When you get down to it, "Dead Rising 2" is nothing more than some dev studio's gameplay concept testing that had AAA graphics wrapped around it.Really.Maybe it's my fault for not doing my homework more thoroughly, but what I thought I was going to get and what I actually got were very different things. I was primed for a roaring trek through a zombie-filled city, where dispatching the undead was hilarious fun and the key to success. The actual game (when I finally got it to work) is a boring loop of backtracking through the same, small piece of real estate, where killing zombies borders on being an afterthought.Maybe "Dead Rising 2" is supposed to be a parody of itself? I don't know. If there's a joke, I'm not getting it.Anyway.The idea of having a very tight time limit on the various goings-on is actually a great idea. It forces you to prioritize and creates a killer sense of tension. The realization that I'd have to find Zombrex for my kiddo, by myself, and on an actual deadline definitely got my attention.The problem is that the thing you would think would be fun and central - taking out zombies - turns out to be boring, clumsy, and peripheral. Combat and associated movement is ponderous and awkward, with a high likelihood that you'll be grappled. There are HUGE delays between an attack animation and the next action, making fights feel walking through quicksand. Kills net you a miniscule amount of experience, and experience is only good for making you incrementally better at...getting kills. Weapons break very quickly, which makes the slog of weapon crafting (pick this up, set it down, pick up another thing, several-second cutscene, off you go) seem monumental after only a few go-arounds....and, as I said, it's peripheral. You don't get anything useful from zombie killing. You don't find anything to trade, which means that combat doesn't provide an alternate path to getting Zombrex for Katy. The zombies apparently respawn, which means that putting a large dent in the population fails to make getting around any easier.Speaking of getting around: The real key to the game (other than the main missions) seems to be going out into the world and bringing folks back. Fair enough, I suppose, but the repetition is boggling. There's exactly one way in and out of the shelter, which means you're going to be seeing the same thing over, and over, and over, and over again while getting bogged down by zombies over, and over, and over, and over again. Once you find somebody, there follows an infuriatingly awkward sequence of trying to talk to them, such that they'll "join" you. The gaps in time between character thoughts being voiced (and anything happening) are so large that you could comfortably taxi a large aircraft through them...and sometimes, the "follow me" script won't trigger on the first attempt.After only a couple of hours, I thought to myself: "If this is going to be the whole game, I think I'll do something else." As I said, the feel of the experience is that a few ideas for some open-world game elements were implemented without regard for how they fit together - and then somehow shipped as a complete product.No, thank you.

I've never quit on a game this early in my 30 years of gaming, but this is one piece of garbage!  I have 149 games in my library not all all of them great, but this is the first game I felt strongly enough about to write a review,  STAY AWAY FROM THIS GAME!!!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												One of my favourite zombie games of all time, alongside the Resident Evil series. Played this on the Xbox 360, but since I prefer computers to consoles now, why not download it on  The game play is fun, bloody and fluid. There are tons of weapons, custom and normal, to find and use on the undead. And on the plus side, the survivor AI is improved and much better than the original Dead Rising (please get a PC release!) The main problems however is the story, launch problems and the voice acting. The story, compared to Dead Rising 1, is kinda crap and lacks the seriousness of the first game. Voice acting can be pretty crap in sections and everyone, despite the fact its meant to be in Nevada, sounds Canadian (I have no quarrells with Canada or Canadians, I have massive respect to the country, as well as family connections). And finally, the launch issues. For some reason, this game will not launch if you have a Windows 8 operating system. But no worries. My trick is to do to your Steam directory, go the SteamApps file, click on Common, right click on Dead Rising 2 exe. and then set the compatibility to Windows 8. Works for me.Overall, this game is fun and brilliant to play. However, this and the third game is not as fantastic as Dead Rising 1(Please get a ♥♥♥♥ing PC release! My day would be complete then!)

content:
Posted: March 15, 2013
												Do not buy, avoid this game. If you need a good Zombie game, then try L2D2 or Dead Island.The most interesting thing in this game seems to be running past stationary zombies and search the next store in the mall for new items or weapons. Not a really interesting thing to do in the long run. Weapons get destroyed after 5-15 hits so you need to replace them constantly. The player cannot do anything else while eating or drinking (= healing yourself in combat). Co-op experience (after you get it working) does not help things at all. Windows Live and conversion from console version hits you right in the face. Playing the game with mouse and keyboard does not really work.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Games For Windows live is working as of Dec 2, 2014 meaning the 360 controller is now recognized and games can be saved through GFWL. You can now recieve phone calls too. When this game becomes supported through steamworks, I hope they include full controller support and everything else works as well. It's supposed to be converted soon, but I'm guessing it won't be until after the first of the year.As far as reviewing this game, I really can't yet, due to limited playtime. I have Dead Rising for the 360 and Dead Rising 2 seems to be more fun than it's predecessor. It certainly has more to offer than the first game, through story, diversity, and the Off The Record dlc, which is supposed to be quite good.For anyone who liked the first game, I say give Dead Rising 2 a try, because it has more to offer. My advice on purchasing, is wait until it's on sale. Like 75% off or more due to this game being more than 4 years old now. I consider it to be one of the better games for pc that often get overlooked or are underrated due to technical issues. Now that GFWL is working again, it's very playable and the technical issues are nonexistent. Once this game is updated to use Steamworks, more people are surely to buy this must play game. If I had to rate this game after only limited gameplay, I would still give it an 8/10 because, this game, clearly has a lot of ppotential.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												I'm quite disappointed in both Capcom and Steam in willfully releasing a game that is fundamentally flawed. No customer should be expected to jump through hoops to try and fix a game that should have been playable out of the box. Steam should especially be ashamed for distributing such a broken game. Would really like to ask for a refund. If you are looking at purchasing this game, please reconsider. It is BROKEN. Also please note, avoid any game that has a third person party packaged with it ie: GFWL. This will also cause you problems. This game could have been a great port, but apparently Capcom and Steam did not feel it necessary to invest the time to fully explore the flaws so prevalent in this game. The "fixes" in the forums are poor excuses for solutions. In fact they are not solutions at all. Once again, a customer should not be expected to have to download, and download, and download again to fix a game that should have been playable to start with. Also, full controller support is a flat out lie. I have an xbox 360 controller, and that option does NOT work.Updated 3/20/15: Since the conversion to Steamworks, Everything seems to be in working order. No longer am I having issues with non existent controller support, ridiculously lengthy loading times, endless GFWL "updating" messages, and just the general malaise associated with the DRM that should never have been spawned. I can now enjoy the zombie splattering madness that only Xbox players could. Cheers.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2013
												A purely great game. Taking place 3 years after Dead Rising: Case Zero, in Fortune City, Nevada the outbreak hits again. You play as Chuck Greene trying to escape the city. And the game has so much unrealism, but that's what makes it fun! Just like the first game, you can kill zombies with nearly everything you can find! Trust me, let's not get into logic, because you can make lightsabers in this game. Well, they're called Laser Swords, but people refer to them as Lightsabers. So I'd rate this game... an 8/10. -1 for the pyschopaths because nearly all of them were seen killing survivors, and a -1 for a short game, but the first one also took 3 days. It's a great game. Get it. Now.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 12, 2011
												The qualities in this game are really a mixed bag. It's far from an action shooter with the focus primarily on melee weapons. The gameplay feels slow for a sandbox style game. If you just want to kill time along with zombies, there is plenty of that to go around, but if you are looking to do missions, you really can't spend time sightseeing due to the time limit. The major weak points are the time limit, the save system, and the fact that the weapons break too quickly. But there are a lot of different weapon combinations you can create and the results always bring a smile to my face. The cut scenes are high quality, but a little on the lengthy side with a lot of them being plain boring. Coop definitely makes it more enjoyable and there is a decent multiplayer experience that reminds me of American Gladiators.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Games For Windows live is working as of Dec 2, 2014 meaning the 360 controller is now recognized and games can be saved through GFWL. You can now recieve phone calls too. When this game becomes supported through steamworks, I hope they include full controller support and everything else works as well. It's supposed to be converted soon, but I'm guessing it won't be until after the first of the year.As far as reviewing this game, I really can't yet, due to limited playtime. I have Dead Rising for the 360 and Dead Rising 2 seems to be more fun than it's predecessor. It certainly has more to offer than the first game, through story, diversity, and the Off The Record dlc, which is supposed to be quite good.For anyone who liked the first game, I say give Dead Rising 2 a try, because it has more to offer. My advice on purchasing, is wait until it's on sale. Like 75% off or more due to this game being more than 4 years old now. I consider it to be one of the better games for pc that often get overlooked or are underrated due to technical issues. Now that GFWL is working again, it's very playable and the technical issues are nonexistent. Once this game is updated to use Steamworks, more people are surely to buy this must play game. If I had to rate this game after only limited gameplay, I would still give it an 8/10 because, this game, clearly has a lot of ppotential.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												There is no other game that I have learned to dispise than this one. I'd rather be playing anything else than this game. This is one of the worst games that i've ever played. The controls are nothing but cumbersome. The game doesn't make sense. It will suck the life and frustration out of you in a heart beat. If mankind has filtered his way into a gameplay that has brought us to this level in gameplay, then just thump everyone that expects the best in what gameplayers expect. I'm embarrassed for the makers of this game. It should have never been made. It would've been better if the missions were not timed. These damn zombie wannabee games like this one is an embarrassment to the industry. Save your money and play something that won't make make you actually vomit in your own mouth. This game definately sucks dookie! I'm a game player and I'll play ANYTHING. I'll try ANYTHING. But this game is beyond the realm of fun. It's a catastrophe! If I ever get constapated and can't crap I'll continue this game where I left off just to keep my bowels working! On the other hands the graphics are great. Maybe I am just not personally up to par with the game engine cause I'm getting to old for the quick reaction without thinking games. Ok, I changed my mind about this game, but I actually had to start it over to do so. I wasted 17 hours into this game before I just started over and had to play it again to actually find some enjoyment in it. It turned out to be a really fun game once how I fugured out just axactly how to play it. Although, I wish the missions were not timed I found a way to acheive the main missions and most of the side missions. What I didn't like was the fact that the game doesn't give you time to explore very much while trying to accomplish every thing through one active gameplay. But, almost all main and side missions can be acheived in one pass through if your good enough. The game is designed to be played more than once, I think. So, that you can play through the main missions first, then restart it over keeping your higher level. And go thorugh all the side missions. But, who wants to do that?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
Dumb & simple zombie killing fun. Like the first game, weapons and health are generally all around you only this time around you can combine two specific items to make another weapon that's possibly cooler, sillier, practical, or a combination of a number of those. You can find out what item goes with what via Combo Cards which are unlocked through general progression of the game such as examining certain posters, leveling, defeating psychopaths, etc. You can combine items without the specific card however the item produced won't be as effective and rewarding. It's highly encouraging to produce the Combo Weapons because using them generally nets you PP for leveling and curiosity in how they'll work will become pretty high.You're free to run around the world as you please (aside from some areas that can only unlocked from doing certain missions) though its criticized time limit makes a return so you only have so much time to get to doing the missions. If you stick to doing missions, not be as distracted, and perhaps if you're at a decent level it won't feel like it's rushing you to go do something so much. Even if you fail a task no matter how important and until the timer runs out or you choose to restart the story you're free to run around freely doing whatever. Restarting the specific save file's story allows you to keep your level, money, and Combo Cards for that next playthrough.The plot & dialogue is full of cheese, especially with the psychopaths. I think it's for the better that that's the case.There isn't much depth to the actual zombie killing aside from just having good weapons for the situation and the psychopath fights. The psychopaths can be extremely cheap in their own special way but at least for most of the fights you're free to leave and return to the area in case you don't feel ready for the boss fight. The co-op's overall doable. A bit easier (if no lag is present) but adds enjoyment to the game. The money and level you've earned anywhere in a save file can be used in both single player and co-op where the only thing that doesn't carry over for either is the story if you're not hosting the game. The entire thing could have probably used an implemented in-game chat and give-item-to-partner feature as opposed to dropping or chucking the item for them to pick it up.Fetch quests, escorts, and just messing around. Probably better with a controller since keys are unrebindable.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												Well I have 12 hours of playtime on this game so time for a review.The game is good. Very good however there are flaws...Firstly this game is an open world hack in slash style game and you have the freedom to go where you want when you want. However you only have 72 hours of gametime (no spoilers) to complete the whole thing so some events are timed and require some management on your behalf but its never been a real issue for me. Side missions include rescuing innocents and killing psychopaths but you have to pick and choose which ones you do so they don't interefere with the main story. Combat is a lot of fun most weapons feel authentic and the crafting system is fun but here is where my biggest issue is. The weapons have very low durability. For the game i understand this as the challenge should be to scavange and find weapons. However since the real high end stuff is really hard to find there is just no point to make the effort if the durability is so low and when you are racing the clock and a massive onslaught of zombies it feels like a massive waste of time. I spend most of my time making Nailed baseball bats because the pieces are right near the home base or even stealing swords from Americana Casino. This issue aside the game is great fun but the multiplayer seems dead if you like co-op play maybe think twice.
