Posted: August 1, 2016
												I've played this game ever since mid-2013 when i pirated it (because ♥♥♥♥ GFWL) and i still enjoy it.Pros+Gameplay is fun (though pretty challenging when you start out)+Graphics are great, but not really phenomenal like how DR1 was at it's time+Lots of zombies on screen with minimal framerate drops (unless you're playing on a toaster PC)+Psychopaths are unique and pretty hard to beat (the texan snipers can go take a hike though(♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s with their cheap shots))+Weapon combinations are fun and sometimes hilarious  and in rare cases, essential   especially when it comes to the Knife Gloves for psychopaths Neutral+- you usually need to replay the game a few times with your level and stats carried over between each playthough (it's worth it, though)+- No Frank West (Off the Record fixed this, though (Case West doesn't count because it's an Xbox 360 exclusive))Cons -The part where the green gas comes in might make you rage quit if you're trying to beat the game for the first time at around level 20-30   especially if you're doing the whole game perfectly with no side quests missed or failed -Co-Op multi with randoms is dead-doesn't have the 2 Xbox 360 exclusive Standalone DLCs (like Case Zero and the afromentioned Case West)Overall score: 8.5/10The game is pretty enjoyable, especially with friends.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2013
												Dead Rising 2 keeps the feel of the original while expanding the size of the map and looking much prettier. That's both good and bad; boss battles are still sprung on you unfairly and are incredibly annoying and frustrating, you'll still lose vast swathes of progress when you forget to go to the bathroom, and you're still going to be tearing your hair out on your first playthrough (especially if you want to save everyone). But it's the same good zombie fun, captures the original's feel very well, and expands on it with new content and features, more zombies, a bigger mall, lots of secrets to uncover, and multiplayer. Well worth the buy, especially if you've got a nice computer. (I've actually played way more hours than it shows, but it doesn't work for me on Steam.)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Coming to the office block was a big mistake. The place was crawling with zombies. The walking dead perambulated throughout the premises as if in a somnambulant haze, a twisted parody of, but not a huge departure from, their former selves. So far I've been lucky and remain undetected, stealth was the right approach as the sound of battle would surely attract the horde.My target had been the Stationery Cupboard. Successfully procuring most of the contents I would soon be able to craft a plethora of makeshift weaponry such as Submachine Guns, Autocannons and Pipe Bombs. It's amazing what you can make out of pens, paper clips, staplers and a few Stick-It Notes in a Zombie Apocalypse. Now all I had to do was get out alive.Crouched amongst a clump of ugly grey office partitions I waited patiently for a nearby zombie to amble past. That's when I made the noob mistake. Moving backwards I inadvertently stepped on a plastic cup. One of those you find at water fountains, a popular congregation spot for malingering employees feigning thirst. The loud crunch it made attracted the attention of the zombie and it immediately began to lurch toward me.As the zombie got closer I could see the ravenous look in its dead eyes. Its gaping maw a cavern full of fetid brown teeth. Its putrid breath reeked of decay and the unmistakable miasma of the walking dead. Initially I was paralysed with terror, then recognition struck. It was Dave, an ex-colleague of mine. A soulless Ginger, now just undead. Poor Dave, he didn't deserve this!Dave stared at me, perhaps a silent entreaty for absolution. I would end his suffering but all I had was a clipboard. Clipboards whilst good for repelling Mall pedestrians are worthless against zombies who are not afraid of marketing surveys. "Get back!" I yelled as I brandished the clipboard menacingly. But Zombie-Dave was relentless. Suddenly it stopped and to my utter astonishment said, "What the frak are you doing? You coming to the meeting or what?"♥♥♥♥♥♥♥edsonofa♥♥♥♥♥! It turned out that the Zombie Apocalypse hadn't started yet and it's just another day at the office. Also, I may have had too many drinks over lunch. Dave's eyes narrowed suspiciously as he spied the boxes of office stationery I cradled protectively in my arms, "You stealing office supplies again?""No!" I yelled in protest. "It's for the Zombie Apocalypse. You'll see." Dave looked dubious as he ambled away."You really should get those teeth looked at," I suggested helpfully, but Dave just waved his hand dismissively without looking back. "Some breath mints would be nice too," I added sotto voce, but Dave was already out of earshot.Dead Rising 2 is an open-world third-person action game set in a fictional casino town beset by a Zombie Apocalypse. The environment is detailed and very well modelled comprising shopping malls, food courts and casinos. A crafting aficionado's dream, there is an incredible amount of paraphernalia about that can be used to craft a veritable cornucopia of zombie-eviscerating weapons from Spiked Bats to Sentry Guns. Some of which are more practical than others, but almost all hilarious. Support items such as health restoring drinks can also be crafted.The main disappointment in the game is in the use of timed missions to create artificial urgency. Each mission has a timer and if not completed in the time allotted results in failure which may end the game. This forces the player to dash from one mission to the next leaving insufficient time for casual exploration and 'playing' with zombies. An untimed sandbox mode would have been nice, but is only available in the standalone remake Off The Record. It is possible to stop the timer using third-party utilities such as CheatEngine, but a modicum of technical ability is required.Being a console port, inventory management seems to be unnecessarily unwieldy for PC players, although overall it seems to be a good port. Definitely one of the better zombie games around and a worthy addition to the Zombie Apocalypse genre.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
												I've played this game ever since mid-2013 when i pirated it (because ♥♥♥♥ GFWL) and i still enjoy it.Pros+Gameplay is fun (though pretty challenging when you start out)+Graphics are great, but not really phenomenal like how DR1 was at it's time+Lots of zombies on screen with minimal framerate drops (unless you're playing on a toaster PC)+Psychopaths are unique and pretty hard to beat (the texan snipers can go take a hike though(♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s with their cheap shots))+Weapon combinations are fun and sometimes hilarious  and in rare cases, essential   especially when it comes to the Knife Gloves for psychopaths Neutral+- you usually need to replay the game a few times with your level and stats carried over between each playthough (it's worth it, though)+- No Frank West (Off the Record fixed this, though (Case West doesn't count because it's an Xbox 360 exclusive))Cons -The part where the green gas comes in might make you rage quit if you're trying to beat the game for the first time at around level 20-30   especially if you're doing the whole game perfectly with no side quests missed or failed -Co-Op multi with randoms is dead-doesn't have the 2 Xbox 360 exclusive Standalone DLCs (like Case Zero and the afromentioned Case West)Overall score: 8.5/10The game is pretty enjoyable, especially with friends.

												Very good and underrated game (thanks to Microsoft Games for Windows Live). Capcom made good job moving this game to Steamworks (I bought this game in box only to use GFWL CD-Key to activate game on Steam, original DVD I have scratched with knife and thrown away, DVD is useless for Steam version). This is very good game about zombie plague with RPG elements and side quests. Game is not scary if you looking for game with horror atmosphere but is fun to play anyway. In this game you saving survivors from zombies and fight with strong psychos. Good thing is also you can combine weapons with really funny effects and you have additional experience for it. I could recommend this game for those people who were disappointed with IHMO highly overrated Left 4 Dead 2 and other people who like games with horde of zombies with co-op mode.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												My friend and I purchased this game with the hope of another great zombie co-op experience. Unfortunately, after playing for a while, it soon became obvious that we were not "quick" enough at playing to meet the timed events that this game asks of the player. If there had been some way to turn the "timer" off to allow us to complete the tasks at our own pace, then some of the other disappointments with the game, like intrusive animations while trying to do something else, could have (perhaps) been overlooked.Eventually, the game came to an end for us because we could neither complete any side quests in the times required, nor could we even complete the MAIN quest (due to the main boss being almost invincible to us) and due to the time to complete running out.A very frustrating game that we had hope to be an enjoyale experience, but which turned out to be  huge disappointment.

Weapons break / use ammo very fast and are often short ranged, which makes harder to eliminate hordes of zombies.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												When you get down to it, "Dead Rising 2" is nothing more than some dev studio's gameplay concept testing that had AAA graphics wrapped around it.Really.Maybe it's my fault for not doing my homework more thoroughly, but what I thought I was going to get and what I actually got were very different things. I was primed for a roaring trek through a zombie-filled city, where dispatching the undead was hilarious fun and the key to success. The actual game (when I finally got it to work) is a boring loop of backtracking through the same, small piece of real estate, where killing zombies borders on being an afterthought.Maybe "Dead Rising 2" is supposed to be a parody of itself? I don't know. If there's a joke, I'm not getting it.Anyway.The idea of having a very tight time limit on the various goings-on is actually a great idea. It forces you to prioritize and creates a killer sense of tension. The realization that I'd have to find Zombrex for my kiddo, by myself, and on an actual deadline definitely got my attention.The problem is that the thing you would think would be fun and central - taking out zombies - turns out to be boring, clumsy, and peripheral. Combat and associated movement is ponderous and awkward, with a high likelihood that you'll be grappled. There are HUGE delays between an attack animation and the next action, making fights feel walking through quicksand. Kills net you a miniscule amount of experience, and experience is only good for making you incrementally better at...getting kills. Weapons break very quickly, which makes the slog of weapon crafting (pick this up, set it down, pick up another thing, several-second cutscene, off you go) seem monumental after only a few go-arounds....and, as I said, it's peripheral. You don't get anything useful from zombie killing. You don't find anything to trade, which means that combat doesn't provide an alternate path to getting Zombrex for Katy. The zombies apparently respawn, which means that putting a large dent in the population fails to make getting around any easier.Speaking of getting around: The real key to the game (other than the main missions) seems to be going out into the world and bringing folks back. Fair enough, I suppose, but the repetition is boggling. There's exactly one way in and out of the shelter, which means you're going to be seeing the same thing over, and over, and over, and over again while getting bogged down by zombies over, and over, and over, and over again. Once you find somebody, there follows an infuriatingly awkward sequence of trying to talk to them, such that they'll "join" you. The gaps in time between character thoughts being voiced (and anything happening) are so large that you could comfortably taxi a large aircraft through them...and sometimes, the "follow me" script won't trigger on the first attempt.After only a couple of hours, I thought to myself: "If this is going to be the whole game, I think I'll do something else." As I said, the feel of the experience is that a few ideas for some open-world game elements were implemented without regard for how they fit together - and then somehow shipped as a complete product.No, thank you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
Dumb & simple zombie killing fun. Like the first game, weapons and health are generally all around you only this time around you can combine two specific items to make another weapon that's possibly cooler, sillier, practical, or a combination of a number of those. You can find out what item goes with what via Combo Cards which are unlocked through general progression of the game such as examining certain posters, leveling, defeating psychopaths, etc. You can combine items without the specific card however the item produced won't be as effective and rewarding. It's highly encouraging to produce the Combo Weapons because using them generally nets you PP for leveling and curiosity in how they'll work will become pretty high.You're free to run around the world as you please (aside from some areas that can only unlocked from doing certain missions) though its criticized time limit makes a return so you only have so much time to get to doing the missions. If you stick to doing missions, not be as distracted, and perhaps if you're at a decent level it won't feel like it's rushing you to go do something so much. Even if you fail a task no matter how important and until the timer runs out or you choose to restart the story you're free to run around freely doing whatever. Restarting the specific save file's story allows you to keep your level, money, and Combo Cards for that next playthrough.The plot & dialogue is full of cheese, especially with the psychopaths. I think it's for the better that that's the case.There isn't much depth to the actual zombie killing aside from just having good weapons for the situation and the psychopath fights. The psychopaths can be extremely cheap in their own special way but at least for most of the fights you're free to leave and return to the area in case you don't feel ready for the boss fight. The co-op's overall doable. A bit easier (if no lag is present) but adds enjoyment to the game. The money and level you've earned anywhere in a save file can be used in both single player and co-op where the only thing that doesn't carry over for either is the story if you're not hosting the game. The entire thing could have probably used an implemented in-game chat and give-item-to-partner feature as opposed to dropping or chucking the item for them to pick it up.Fetch quests, escorts, and just messing around. Probably better with a controller since keys are unrebindable.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Dead Rising 2 is a game developed and published by Capcom and is the sequel to Dead Rising. Think Saints Row, both game series are silly in their own ways. With Dead Rising, you have a number of fun weapons and clothes to try outWith the levelling system present, the game allows you to start a new game using your progress from your previous save, making the game much easier for you, especially to complete the side-missions and defeat psychopathsThe day/night cycle makes the world feel real rather than constantly having the game at night just because it's a zombie game. It also gives challenge to the player, to either stay inside the shelter and wait out night time or to risk going out at night having to deal with stronger zombies but with a potentially more rewarding experienceThere is a wide variety of weapons to choose from in the game. The combat is not terrible, just that I felt it wasn't very smooth and fluid. Trying to aim with a weapon can be difficult especially since you're not able to move when you're aiming the gun or to throw a weapon. Fighting against psychopaths, especially when you're still starting the game can be very frustratingThe Survivor AI is just terrible, you encounter survivors who say they want to live but as you try to escort them and look back, they're often standing still or running slowly as if they want to be eaten alive. You can give them a weapon for their self-defense but it's not like they'll be able to use it effectively. It's infuriating but pretty satisfying when you're actually able to escort at least two or more at once to the shelter thoughThe waypoint system is sort of a triangle, you're at point A, you want to reach to point C without looking at the map so you trust the waypoint system to lead you there, so you keep following the waypoint until you realise it made you take a detour through point B even though the risk of going straight to point C or taking the detour is more or less the same, just that you wasted an amount of time because of the waypoint system. Seriously, you're better off navigating on your own using the map. It's as if it was designed to waste the player's time as much as possible. Once you've played enough of the game you'll probably remember all the locations anywayDead Rising 2 has a time limit system for the missions, in which you only have a limited amount of time to complete missions. You're able to ignore the missions but with consequences, you might lose survivors when skipping side missions and you won't be able to continue playing the main mission if you skip them. However, you're still able to continue on playing freeroam after skipping and failing the main missionDead Rising 2 can be quite challenging, especially with the lack of difficulty choices, save locations and the stupid survivor AI, however it is a good continuation to a fantastic zombie series! RECOMMENDED :)

												This game and OTR are considered the strongest in the series, imo.Dead Rising 2 is considered as one of the best sequels ever, though it's underrated.It fixed a lot of issues, first game had,to be exact:-A.I. THANK GOD!!!!!OH MY GOD!!!!!!!!Yes, A.I. became finally intelligent. SO many nerves in my brains can now rest with great pleasure.Before you ask,YES, it was THAT important and everybody were happy-Combo Weapons. Major invention for the series, that eventually became the norm for the series.Shortly, another best thing , that was added to the sequel.-A bit easier bosses. A BIT. Yeah,might not mean much, but after 1st game, it is a lot.-Not-so-steep difficulty curveAnd so much more...Overall,this game scored less than the 1st game,BUT this game is great.The only issue I have is broken co-op.GFWL,that's enough,but it was only for co-op,so singleplayer had no issues.Highly recommended!P.S.: If you bought all the DLC's for the 2nd game,you can easily break the game, as clothes are too OP ,especially if you started new game(No kidding!)

content:
Posted: December 6, 2010
												Surely, any game that starts you out with killing tons of zombies with a bike with two chainsaws put on it is gonna be crazy, right? Well...Yes, this game is crazy. It can go way over the top, but only if you want it to. And that gets us to the main strength of this game, in which you fight off a zombie apocalypse with all kinds of weapons - how much you can do in it. Rescue survivors, kill zombies with tons of weird weapons (including custom ones), co-op with a friend, and more.In Dead Rising 2, you play as Chuck, who gets stuck in the middle of a giant zombie outbreak, and then gets blaimed for starting it all. But that's not all - Chuck has a daughter who was once bitten by a zombie, and now requires a daily dose of a drug named Zombrex - which is, ofcourse, very rare. So, you'll have to guide Chuck through a zombie-infested entertainment resort, trying to clear your name while in the mean time getting your daughter her Zombrex doses. Running outta space here, go buy it. :p

content:
Posted: February 13
												A good sequel to an already great first entry in the series.It keeps the elements that made the first Dead Rising great and enhances it even further, even by having new modes such as the long awaited co-op! If you liked the first one, then go ahead and buy this one without a doubt. And If you weren't a big fan of the first game, then the changes made to this one might be right up your alley, such as: an easier difficulty overall while still managing to keep the game challenging, survivors are a LOT easier to escort, and the time isn't as strict as the previous game.PS: The game has been updated with trading cards, achievements, and now it uses Steamworks instead of Games For Windows Live.You can also import your older saves to this new version but unfortunately the achievements won't be carried over.
